id="_bookmark1"></a>Abstract</h2><p>The present document specifies the characteristics of the system called Converged Multimedia Telephony (MMTEL) Application Server (AS) provided by Mavenir Systems, which will be referred to as CTAS throughout this document. The CTAS is an IMS and GSMA IR.92 compliant Application Server which provides the following high level functions:</p><ul><li>MMTEL supplementary services</li><li>XCAP server for supplementary service configuration operations made via the Ut interface</li><li>Integrated IM-SSF</li><li>Integrated SCC AS</li><li>Integrated Ring Back Tones (RBT) service</li><li>Charging Trigger Function (CTF) for offline charging via Rf interface</li><li>Charging Trigger Function (CTF) for online charging via Ro Interface</li><li>USSI AS</li></ul><p>Note that the integrated IM-SSF function is not covered in this document. For details on this component, please refer to the IM-SSF IN-IW Use Cases.</p><h2><a id="1.2 Target Audience"></a><a id="_bookmark2"></a><a id="_bookmark2"></a>Target Audience</h2><p>Teams working Protocol</p></td></tr></table><h1><a id="4 System Overview"></a><a id="_bookmark49"></a><a id="_bookmark49"></a>System Overview</h1><p>In the IMS architecture, the Converged MMTEL Telephony Application Server (CTAS) provides multimedia telephony service and supplementary services as defined in 3GPP specifications and according to operator’s specific requirements.</p><p>In addition, the CTAS supports two key integrated functions:</p><ul><li>An integrated Service Centralization and Continuity (SCC) function provides 3GPP compliant SCC AS functionality. This includes support for session anchoring, terminating access domain selection (T-ADS) and PS to CS SR-VCC access transfer.</li><li>An integrated gsmSSF/IM-SSF function provides a 3GPP compliant O-BCSM/T-BCSM and IN interworking, offering IN services to IMS subscribers using the operator’s existing SCPs. This also includes an integrated gsmSRF function.</li><li>An integrated gsmSCF function providing similar service as that of the IN SCP. The current service is limited to enable redirection of CS calls (originated or terminated) into the IMS domain for the purpose of ICS.</li></ul><p>Note:\tThe integrated IM-SSF function is not covered in this document. For details on this component, please refer to the <a href="#_bookmark26">[37].</a></p><p>The complete list of supplementary services supported at CTAS is:</p><ul><li>Originating Identity Presentation (OIP) and Restriction (OIR)</li><li>Terminating Identity Presentation (TIP) and Restriction (TIR)</li><li>Communication Diversion (CDIV)</li><li>Conference (CONF)</li><li>Communication Hold (HOLD)</li><li>Communication Barring (CB)</li><li>Operator Determined Barring (ODB)</li><li>Communication Waiting (CW)</li><li>Completion of Communications to Busy Subscriber (CCBS)</li><li>Ring Back Tone (RBT)</li></ul><p>Additional services supported at CTAS are:</p><ul><li>Originating USSD services</li><li>IN services (CAP2, CAP3, CAP4) via the integrated gsmSSF/IM-SSF with an internal gsmSRF</li><li>IN Services (INAP CS-1, CS-2) via the integrated gsmSSF/IM-SSF with an internal gsmSRF</li><li>CS Redirection service via the integrated gsmSCF using CAP2, CAP3, INAP CS-1, CS-2 and ANSI-41 ver E based WIN.</li><li>Multi UA Registration</li><li>Multi-SIM services</li><li>Multi UA forking</li><li>Intra IMPU Call Transfer (Pull and Push)</li><li>User interrogation and configuration of supplementary services</li><li>Announcement and tones</li></ul><p>CTAS also has an inbuilt Service Brokering (SB) functionality which manages service interactions among services and functions hosted within the CTAS. This SB function manages invocations and interactions of one or more services based on predefined service detection and resolution information.</p><p>CTAS also provides a flexible and configurable translations framework. This is described in detail in the CTAS Translations Functional Description <a href="#_bookmark25">[36].</a></p><p>These services are described in greater detail later in this document, or in other referenced documentation.</p><h1><a id="5 Design Considerations"></a><a id="_bookmark50"></a><a id="_bookmark50"></a>Design Considerations</h1><h2><a id="5.1 Assumptions and Dependencies"></a><a id="_bookmark51"></a><a id="_bookmark51"></a>Assumptions and Dependencies</h2><p>The following are the assumptions and dependencies related to the delivered functionality:</p><ul><li>The S-CSCF should anchor the subscriber to a particular CTAS instance for the lifetime of the IMS registration.</li><li>The S-CSCF must include an Authorization header containing the IMPI of the served user in the embedded REGISTER request message of the 3rd party REGISTER generated for the network initiated de-registration scenario.</li><li>The S-CSCF must include the embedded UE REGISTER request and 200 OK response in the 3rd party REGISTER request generated as a result of Initial, Refresh, network-initiated de-registration and user initiated de-registration. In the former case, the REGISTER and 200 OK are built by the S-CSCF as no message from the UE is involved.</li><li>The S-CSCF must support a “reg” event subscription from the CTAS with an Expires header containing a zero or non-zero value. In addition to the full registration state information for all registered contacts, the S-CSCF will include the following relevant information for every Contact address included:<ul><li>sip.instance representing either the IMEI-URN provided by the UE or the UUID generated by the S-CSCF</li><li>Other Contact header field parameter including the feature tags like icsi.mmtel, etc.</li><li>IMPI</li><li>ATCF mgmt. URI</li><li>PANI (UE provided and/or network provided)</li><li>PVNI</li></ul></li></ul><p>The last three requires non-standard implementation at the S-CSCF.</p><ul><li>The S-CSCF must add a P-Served-User header as defined in RFC 5502 to any non-REGISTER request before sending the request to the CTAS.</li><li>The initial INVITE request received may or may not contain a valid P-Access-Network-Info corresponding to the registered contact. The lack of P-Access-Network-Info will introduce a limitation at CTAS for profile recovery as the CGI is mandatory for any IN transactions.</li><li>Upon network initiated de-registration, the S-CSCF should comply with the sub-clause defined in 24.229, section 5.4.1.4.1, and ensure only those dialogs initiated by or terminated towards the user’s IMS contact address should be cleared. Failure to comply would cause clearing of the active dialog of the forwarding user, or the clearing of calls which were terminated in the CS domain.</li><li>UAs are expected to support P-Early-Media (PEM) header as defined in RFC 5009.<ul><li>When early media is to be authorized in the backward direction, the UAS is expected to insert a P-Early-Media header with a value of “sendonly” in a 183 provisional response containing the SDP answer.</li><li>An absence of a PEM header or a PEM header with a value of “inactive” in the18x provisional response indicates that early media is not authorized and this should trigger the originating UA to play local ringback when the 180 Ringing is received.</li></ul></li><li>UAs are expected to comply with SDP offer/answer handling as defined in RFC 6337.</li><li>The UAs are expected to support the UPDATE method and indicate the same by including it in the Allow header of originating INVITE request or 18x / 200 OK response in case of terminating user. If Allow header is not included, it is assumed that UPDATE method is supported. In general, the same assumption is made for all other methods.</li><li>The O-MGCF node is expected to support the History-Info header and interwork redirection information received to History-Info header in the INVITE request.</li><li>The MGCF will support including the Reason header in the 183 Session in Progress response when a Cause indicator is received in CPG or ACM.</li><li>In the presence of multiple early dialogs with SDP offer/answer exchanged in one or more of the early dialogs, the P-CSCF/A-BGF may perform media gate control procedures (or latching) using the remote SDP information. But must selectively open the gate corresponding to an authorized early media flow based on the P-Early-Media header.<ul><li>P-Early-Media with a value of “sendonly” must be considered as early media authorized.</li><li>P-Early-Media with a value of “inactive” must be considered as early media not authorized.</li><li>P-Early-Media header being omitted must be considered as early media not authorized.</li><li>When the P-Early-Media header is not included, the value for PEM which is currently in effect is not updated/changed, i.e. the previously received value for the early-dialog is (still) in effect.</li><li>The P-Early-Media header indicating early media authorization may also be included in UPDATE request.</li><li>The media gating will be based on the last received P-Early-Media header value on any existing or new early dialogs and if the header is omitted in the last message received on any existing or new early dialogs or included with a value of “inactive”, the previously received value for the respective early dialog will be in effect.</li></ul></li><li>The EPC or IMS HSS FE must support the Notif-Eff feature as described in 3GPP TS 29.328 to allow the CTAS to retrieve multiple data items within a single Sh UDR/SNR query.<ul><li>Lack of support would require multiple Sh UDR/SNR queries to be performed when the CTAS requires data associated with multiple Sh data references.</li></ul></li><li>P-CSCF serving the subscribers (own or roamers) will include P-Visited-Network-Id header in the UE REGISTER request with a value indicating “HPLMN” or “VPLMN” identity in this format: epc.ims.mnc&lt;MNC&gt;.mcc&lt;MCC&gt;.3gppnetwork.org (according to GSMA IR.65) or simply a domain name identifying the attached HPLMN/VPLMN.</li><li>IMS HSS must support receiving SNR with “Send-Data-Indication” AVP.</li></ul><h2><a id="5.2 General Constraints"></a><a id="_bookmark52"></a><a id="_bookmark52"></a>General Constraints</h2><p>CTAS’s compliance to the relevant 3GPP standards is defined in the detailed Mavenir VoLTE Standards Compliance document <a href="#_bookmark4">[1].</a></p><h1><a id="6 Architecture"></a><a id="_bookmark53"></a><a id="_bookmark53"></a>Architecture</h1><h2><a id="6.1 Overall Functional Architecture"></a><a id="_bookmark54"></a><a id="_bookmark54"></a>Overall Functional Architecture</h2><p>The following diagram depicts the CTAS interfaces required to achieve the functionality defined within this document.</p><p>UDR</p><p>  </p><p>CDMA HLR FE</p><p>GSM</p><p>HLR FE</p><p>EPC</p><p>HSS FE</p><p>MAP ANSI-41 but this is not mandatory. The UDR in the above picture could also be replaced with an IMS HSS.</li></ul><p>The following table summarizes the CTAS interface in this release. These are described in subsequent sections.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Peer Node/System</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Application Protocol</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>S-CSCF</p></td><td><p>SIP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>I-CSCF</p></td><td><p>SIP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>AP</p></td><td><p>XCAP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>EPC HSS FE</p></td><td><p>Diameter</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>IMS HSS FE</p></td><td><p>Diameter</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>HLR</p></td><td><p>MAP, ANSI-41</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>UDR</p></td><td><p>LDAP SOAP</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Peer Node/System</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Application Protocol</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SCP</p></td><td><p>CAP INAP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDF</p></td><td><p>Diameter</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>MRF</p></td><td><p>SIP / MSML</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>AMDF</p></td><td><p>SOAP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>DF2</p></td><td><p>XML</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>iDNS</p></td><td><p>DNS</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>ENUM FE</p></td><td><p>ENUM/DNS</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OCF</p></td><td><p>Diameter</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SDM</p></td><td><p>SIP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>GLS</p></td><td><p>SOAP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>iHLR</p></td><td><p>SOAP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CNAM DB</p></td><td><p>TCAP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SSF</p></td><td><p>CAP INAP ANSI41</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>DND DB</p></td><td><p>Diameter</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CCPS</p></td><td><p>SOAP</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="6.1.1 Interface: CTAS to S-CSCF"></a><a id="_bookmark55"></a><a id="_bookmark55"></a>Interface: CTAS to S-CSCF</h3><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined ISC interface to the S-CSCF. The protocol used on this interface is SIP. Both UDP and TCP transport are supported. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>Depending on the features invoked by the user, the CTAS may act in one of the following roles on this interface:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Routing B2BUA using 3rd party call control</li><li>Initiating B2BUA using 3rd party call control</li><li>Originating UA</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The CTAS never acts as a SIP proxy.</p><p>The following sections describe this interface and the interactions with the S-CSCF in greater detail.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.1 Determination of served user typ"></a><a id="_bookmark56"></a><a id="_bookmark56"></a>Determination of served user type</h4><p>A single CTAS instance may support serving the originating user or the terminating user. Upon receipt of an initial INVITE request, the CTAS must determine the type of user so that it can then determine the services to provide. There are three main types of users supported by the CTAS, and the CTAS relies on the presence or absence of parameters within the top most Route header to make this determination. The S-CSCF must copy these Route header parameters transparently from the SIP URI of CTAS configured in the initial Filter Criteria (iFC) of the user profile. It is there for a configuration exercise to determine the type of user.</p><p>The types of users and how they are determined is as follows:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ol><li>Originating user</li></ol></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The CTAS serving the originating user determines the served user’s identity via the SIP headers below, in the order specified:</p><p>P-Served-User</p><p>P-Asserted-Identity</p><p>From</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ol><li>Terminating VoLTE user</li></ol></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The CTAS serving the terminating VoLTE user determines the served user’s identity in the order specified below:</p><p>P-Served-User</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ol><li>Terminating non-VoLTE user</li></ol></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The CTAS serving the terminating VoLTE user determines the served user’s identity in the order specified below:</p><p>Request-URI</p><p>The CTAS acts as a B2BUA and 3rd party call controller for providing the MMTel services and other features. Depending on the services and features invoked, the CTAS may perform in any mode of operation defined below:</p><ul><li>Routing B2BUA – CTAS receives a request for a dialog from a UAC (via the S-CSCF), terminates the dialog (i.e. acts as a UAS) and generates a new request for a dialog (i.e. acts as a UAC), which is based on the received request.</li><li>Initiating B2BUA – CTAS initiates request(s) for a dialog (i.e. acts as a UAC) on behalf of hosted subscriber(s), which may be logically connected together at the AS.</li><li>Originating UA – CTAS generates an originating request for a dialog (i.e. acts as a UAC) and sends it to the S-CSCF.</li></ul><p>The following section defines the interaction between the CTAS and the S-CSCF based on the mode of operation.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.2 Originating Trigger (Routing B2B"></a><a id="_bookmark57"></a><a id="_bookmark57"></a>Originating Trigger (Routing B2BUA)</h4><p>When an Initial INVITE request is received at the CTAS, it determines the session case based on the service token present in the topmost Route header. If the topmost Route header contains the service token identifying session case of originating, the request is considered to be origination request. CTAS processes the request received, applies any originating services and acts as a routing B2BUA to route the request to the S-CSCF based on the SIP URI in the Route header that is copied into the outgoing message from the incoming request.</p><p>CTAS can identify the originating trigger based on the following:</p><ul><li>Session case included in the P-Served-User header field parameter of “sesscase=orig”;</li><li>If P-Served-User is not available or sesscase is not included,“orig” as URI parameter in the top most Route header containing AS address information</li></ul><h4><a id="6.1.1.3 Terminating Trigger (Routing B2B"></a><a id="_bookmark58"></a><a id="_bookmark58"></a>Terminating Trigger (Routing B2BUA)</h4><p>When an Initial INVITE Request is received at the CTAS, if the service token identifying an originating session case is not present in the topmost Route header, the request is considered to be a termination request. The CTAS processes the request received, applies any terminating services and acts as a routing B2BUA to route the request to the S-CSCF based on the SIP URI in Route header that is copied into the outgoing message from the incoming request.</p><p>CTAS can identify the originating trigger based on the following:</p><ul><li>Session case included in the P-Served-User header field parameter of “sesscase=term”;</li><li>If P-Served-User is not available or sesscase is not included, No “orig” indicator received in the top most Route header containing AS address information</li></ul><h4><a id="6.1.1.4 Terminating Unregistered Trigger"></a><a id="_bookmark59"></a><a id="_bookmark59"></a>Terminating Unregistered Trigger (Routing B2BUA)</h4><p>When an Initial INVITE request is received for termination, if the served user is not registered, the CTAS will treat it as a Terminating unregistered request. The CTAS processes the request received, applies any terminating unregistered services and acts as a routing B2BUA to route the request to the S-CSCF based on the SIP URI in Route header that is copied into the outgoing message from the incoming request.</p><p>CTAS identifies the terminating unregistered trigger by checking the registration-state-param in the P- Served-User header. If the regstate param is set to a value of “unreg”, the request is considered to be an unregistered termination request.</p><p>If P-Served-User header is not supported by the S-CSCF, the CTAS will identify unregistered termination based on the presence of “unreg” token in the topmost Route header of the incoming INVITE for termination.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.5 Requests initiated by the CTAS ("></a><a id="_bookmark60"></a><a id="_bookmark60"></a>Requests initiated by the CTAS (Initiating B2BUA)</h4><p>When the served terminating user has Multi-SIM feature subscription, the CTAS acting as an Initiating B2BUA initiates new call requests on behalf of the served user to one or more Multi-SIM members which are part of the same Multi-SIM subscription group. The requests routed as part of this feature will be routed to the S-CSCF based on the SIP URI in the Route header that is copied into the outgoing message from the incoming request.</p><p>Refer to the Multi-SIM Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark20">[31] </a>for more details.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.6 Requests originated by the CTAS "></a><a id="_bookmark61"></a><a id="_bookmark61"></a>Requests originated by the CTAS (Originating UA)</h4><p>When the call terminated to the served user is applied CDIV service, the CTAS serving the terminating user will act as an Originating UA and will initiate an originating request on behalf of the served user. The CTAS will insert a Route header field pointing to the S-CSCF where the public user identity on whose behalf the request is generated is registered and append the “orig” parameter to the URI in the topmost Route header field. The P-Served-User header is included with the identity of the served user.</p><p>Refer to the CDIV Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark24">[35] </a>for more details.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.7 SIP Methods"></a><a id="_bookmark62"></a><a id="_bookmark62"></a>SIP Methods</h4><p>The following table summarizes the SIP method support on the ISC interface.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Method</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Sent</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Received</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>REGISTER</p></td><td></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>INVITE</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>ACK</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>BYE</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CANCEL</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>UPDATE</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>PRACK</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SUBSCRIBE</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>NOTIFY</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>MESSAGE</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Method</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Sent</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Received</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>REFER</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OPTIONS</p></td><td></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>INFO</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr></table><h4><a id="6.1.1.8 SIP Headers"></a><a id="_bookmark63"></a><a id="_bookmark63"></a>SIP Headers</h4><p>The SIP headers defined below are those which are relevant for the CTAS service logic. If any header not listed here is received, the CTAS will transparently relay the header.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Header</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Sent on ISC</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Received on ISC</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Accept</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Accept-Contact</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Allow</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Call-ID</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Contact</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Content-Disposition</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Content-Length</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Content-Type</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Cseq</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Event</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Expires</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>From</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>History-Info</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Info-Package</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Max-Forwards</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Min-expires</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Min-SE</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>P-Asserted-Identity</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>P-Served-User</p></td><td><p>X</p><p>(originating)</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>P-Access-Network-Info</p></td><td><p>X</p><p>(routing)</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>P-Charging-Vector</p></td><td><p>X</p><p>(routing, initiating, originating)</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>P-Visited-Network-ID</p></td><td><p>X</p><p>(routing)</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>P-Early-Media</p></td><td><p>X</p><p>(routing, initiating, originating)</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Privacy</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Header</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Sent on ISC</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Received on ISC</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Rack</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Reason</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Record-Route</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Recv-Info</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Request-Disposition</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Require</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Route</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Rseq</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Session-Expires</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Subscription-State</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Supported</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>To</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Via</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr></table><p>As a default B2BUA function, the CTAS will transparently pass supported and unsupported signalling elements (e.g. SIP headers, SIP messages bodies), except signalling elements that are modified or deleted as part of the hosted service logic. As part of B2BUA function, the Contact URI will be rewritten, but the URI parameter which includes the feature tags received in the incoming request will be copied over to the outgoing request.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.9 SIP Event Packages"></a><a id="_bookmark64"></a><a id="_bookmark64"></a>SIP Event Packages</h4><p>The following SIP event packages are supported.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Event Package</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Sent</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Received</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>reg</p></td><td></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>conference</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>call-completion</p></td><td><p>X</p></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>dialog</p></td><td></td><td><p>X</p></td></tr></table><p>Receipt of a SUBSCRIBE request for any other event package will result in CTAS sending a 489 Bad Event response.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.10 3rd Party Registration"></a><a id="_bookmark65"></a><a id="_bookmark65"></a>3<sup>rd</sup> Party Registration</h4><p>The CTAS supports 3rd party registration of subscribers by the S-CSCF. CTAS relies on the 3rd party REGISTER request containing an embedded UE REGISTER and 200 OK response for the retrieval of necessary registration data. This in turn requires that the iFCs be configured appropriate to trigger the inclusion of this information, i.e. via the &lt;IncludeRegisterRequest&gt; and &lt;IncludeRegisterResponse&gt; tags.</p><p>As part of this procedure, the CTAS will retrieve the subscriber’s user profile from the UDR/HSS and cache it locally. It will also retrieve the non-subscriber data associated with the subscriber’s user profile and cache it locally.</p><p>The table below summarizes the information relevant to the served user extracted from the embedded UE REGISTER request and 200 OK response:</p><table><tr><td></td><td><p><strong>UE REGISTER</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>UE 200 OK</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CGI/eCGI</p></td><td><p>One or Two P-Access-Network-Info. “np” (network-provided) P-Access- Network-Info header if available, is given higher priority. If “np” PANI is not available top most PANI is used.</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><p>VLR</p><p>Address/VPLMN Id</p></td><td><p>P-Visited-Network-Id</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><p>Instance-Id</p></td><td><p>“sip.instance” media feature tag included in the Contact header field</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><p>IMEI/IMEISV</p></td><td><p>“sip.instance” media feature tag included in the Contact header field in IMEI URN format as defined in RFC 7254</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><p>IMSI</p></td><td><p>IMPI included in the Authorization header in "&lt;IMSI&gt;@ims.mnc&lt;MNC&gt;.mcc&lt;MC C&gt;.3gppnetwork.org" format.</p><p>If the host portion of the IMPI is not in the format defined above, and if configuration control is enabled, the user part is assumed to be IMSI.</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><p>Implicitly Registered Identities</p></td><td></td><td><p>P-Associated-URI</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Rel 10 SRVCC</p><p>Information</p></td><td><p>Feature-Caps header or Path header containing ATCF-URI, STN-SR and ATU-Mgmt-URI. Additionally</p><p>Feature-Caps header can contain g.3gpp.mid-call, g.3gpp.srvcc- alerting and 3gpp.ps2cs-srvcc-orig- pre-alerting feature-capability indicator.</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td><p>UE IP</p></td><td><p>Contact header URI parameter. The parameter name carrying the UE IP is configurable.</p></td><td></td></tr><tr><td></td><td></td><td><p>Contact header field is analyzed to check for mismatch in the contact binding between the S-CSCF and the TAS. If mismatch is found, profile recovery is triggered.</p></td></tr></table><h4><a id="6.1.1.11 Addressing"></a><a id="_bookmark66"></a><a id="_bookmark66"></a>Addressing</h4><p>The CTAS supports user identities received in the following formats:</p><ul><li>SIP URI containing the user’s MSISDN in the user part, with or without the “user=phone” parameter</li><li>TEL URI containing the user’s MSISDN</li></ul><p>IMS subscribers at operator network can be configured with both of these identities included in a single implicit registration set.</p><p>CTAS also supports both Distinct PSIs and Wildcarded PSIs in either SIP URI or TEL URI format.</p><p>CTAS does not support the “phone-context” or “user=dialstring” parameter. If received, it will be ignored.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.12 Parallel Early Dialogs"></a><a id="_bookmark67"></a><a id="_bookmark67"></a>Parallel Early Dialogs</h4><p>CTAS supports establishing multiple early dialogs towards an originating UA which indicates support for forking by either not sending the fork directive or by sending a fork directive with a value of “fork”. CTAS supports maintaining a maximum of 8 parallel early dialogs with early media authorized in only one of them, in alignment with GSMA IR.92.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.13 Preconditions"></a><a id="_bookmark68"></a><a id="_bookmark68"></a>Preconditions</h4><p>CTAS supports the resource reservation framework defined in RFC 3312, otherwise known as preconditions.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.14 Offer/Answer Model"></a><a id="_bookmark69"></a><a id="_bookmark69"></a>Offer/Answer Model</h4><p>CTAS supports the offer/answer model as defined in RFC 3264. CTAS uses the UPDATE method to send subsequent SDP offers within an early dialog and uses the INVITE method to send subsequent SDP offers within a confirmed dialog. If there is a change in the SDP version ID and if the SDP answer received in 200 OK response to the UPDATE/re-INVITE request has changed, the CTAS generates an UPDATE/re-INVITE request to the remote party.</p><h4><a id="6.1.1.15 “cpc” URI parameter"></a><a id="_bookmark70"></a><a id="_bookmark70"></a>“cpc” URI parameter</h4><p>The originating CTAS will support a function that adds the Calling Party’s Category (cpc) parameter in the P-Asserted-Identity header field. Enabling and disabling this function will be configurable by the operator.</p><p>If the function is enabled, the originating CTAS will add the Calling Party’s Category (cpc) parameter in the P-Asserted-Identity header field that is represented in the tel-URI scheme as specified in 3GPP TS 24.229, section 7.2A.12.</p><p><em>Note 1: The P-Asserted-Identity header field generated by the P-CSCF in sip-URI scheme does not include the user=phone parameter and is therefore not a sip-URI representation of a telephone number. The P-Asserted-Identity header field in the tel-URI scheme is generated by the originating S-CSCF according to 3GPP TS 24.607, section 4.3.2, Note 2.</em></p><p>If the function is enabled, the originating TAS shall generate the Calling Party’s Category (cpc) as follows:</p><ul><li>If the received initial INVITE includes the authorized Resource-Priority header field the originating CTAS will generate the Calling Party’s Category (cpc) with a value that can be configured by the operator. The default configured cpc-value will be “priority”.</li></ul><p>Note 2: The cpc-value “priority” is not specified in 3GPP TS 24.229.</p><ul><li>If the received initial INVITE does not include the authorized Resource-Priority header field the originating CTAS will generate the Calling Party’s Category (cpc) with a value that can be configured by the operator. The default configured cpc-value will be “mobile-hplmn”.</li></ul><h3><a id="6.1.2 Interface: CTAS to I-CSCF"></a><a id="_bookmark71"></a><a id="_bookmark71"></a>Interface: CTAS to I-CSCF</h3><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Ma interface to the I-CSCF. The protocol used on this interface is SIP. Both UDP and TCP transport are supported. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>The Ma interface is used by the I-CSCF to direct SIP requests which are addressed to a Public Service Identity (PSI) directly to the Application Server which hosts that PSI. Use cases for PSIs and the Ma interface in this release include:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Subscriptions to the “conference” event package for MMTEL conferences</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>These SUBSCRIBE requests are addressed to Conference URIs allocated by CTAS at the time of conference creation. These Conference URIs are treated as wildcarded PSIs in the IMS</p><p>network, with each PSI resolving to the address of the CTAS that is hosting that particular conference. Refer to the Conferencing Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark19">[30] </a>for further details.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Subscriptions to the “call-completion” event package for CCBS feature</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>These SUBSCRIBE requests are addressed to the terminating network (CTAS or MGCF) hosting the recipient of the original call which has triggered CC-Possible indication in the 486 Busy response.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Access transfer session requests</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>These INVITE requests are addressed to the ATU-STI allocated by the SCC function of the CTAS. These ATU-STIs are treated as distinct PSIs in the IMS network, with each PSI resolving to the address of the CTAS that is anchoring the call that is undergoing the SR-VCC access transfer.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>CCBS Re-call Termination requests</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>These INVITE requests are addressed to destination B for which call completion was requested by the originating user, after destination B becomes free and a CC call has been setup with the originating user.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>STN based Call Transfer requests</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>These INVITE requests are addressed to the STN which is a pre-defined service identifier for the service being invoked.</p><h3><a id="6.1.3 Interface: CTAS to AP"></a><a id="_bookmark72"></a><a id="_bookmark72"></a>Interface: CTAS to AP</h3><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Ut interface to the HEP, as defined in 3GPP 24.623. The protocol used on this interface is XCAP, as defined in RFC 4825. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6. This interface also supports HTTP over Transport Layer Security (HTTPS)</p><p>The Ut interface signaling is originated by the UE but traverses the HEP for authentication purposes. The Ut interface is used by the UE to interrogate and modify supplementary service configuration, which is carried within the “simservs” XML document within the XCAP requests and responses. CTAS supports Ut requests which operate on the entire XML document, and also supports node selector functionality which allows Ut requests to operate on specific elements or attributes within the XML document.</p><p>Refer to the Ut Interface Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark21">[32] </a>for further details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.4 Interface: CTAS to EPC HSS FE"></a><a id="_bookmark73"></a><a id="_bookmark73"></a>Interface: CTAS to EPC HSS FE</h3><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Sh interface to the EPC HSS FE as defined in 3GPP 29.328 and</p><p>29.329. The base protocol used on this interface is Diameter as defined in RFC 3588. Both TCP and SCTP transport are supported for this interface. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>This interface is used by CTAS to retrieve information from the UDR/HSS for call routing logic, including special logic required for the Multi-SIM feature. The following Sh data reference values are supported in the Sh UDR commands in this release:</p><ul><li>UserState (data reference 15)</li></ul><p>This query, along with a Requested-Domain AVP set to “CS-Domain”, is used to retrieve the subscriber’s state in the CS network.</p><ul><li>LocationInformation (data reference 14)</li></ul><p>This query, along with a Requested-Domain AVP set to “CS-Domain”, is used to retrieve the subscriber’s VLR number in the CS network. When CS breakout or retry is performed, this information is used to determine the roaming status of the subscriber.</p><ul><li>TADSInformation (data reference 26)</li></ul><p>This query is used to determine whether IMS voice over PS is supported on the current access network.</p><ul><li>STN-SR (data reference 27)</li></ul><p>This query is used to determine whether the Session Transfer Number for SRVCC (STN-SR) is configured for a subscriber in the HSS.</p><ul><li>UE-SRVCC-Capability (data reference 28)</li></ul><p>This query is used to determine whether the UE is SRVCC capable or not.</p><ul><li>CSRN (data reference 30)</li></ul><p>This query is used to retrieve the CS domain Routing Number for a subscriber while performing CS breakout or CS retry.</p><p>The following Sh data reference values are supported in the Sh PUR commands in this release:</p><ul><li>STN-SR (data reference 27)</li></ul><p>This update is used to update STN-SR for a subscriber in the HSS.</p><p>All Sh UDR commands are sent with the subscriber’s Master MSISDN in the User-Identity AVP and an IMSI in the User-Name AVP, which allows each query to be device-specific.</p><p>CTAS supports and uses the Notif-Eff feature defined for the Sh interface, which allows a single Sh UDR command to identify multiple data reference values, which in turn allows all requested data to be returned in a single Sh UDA command.</p><p>Refer to the CTAS Multi-SIM Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark20">[31] </a>and CTAS Sh Interface specification <a href="#_bookmark37">[50] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.5 Interface: CTAS to IMS HSS FE"></a><a id="_bookmark74"></a><a id="_bookmark74"></a>Interface: CTAS to IMS HSS FE</h3><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Sh interface to the IMS HSS FE as defined in 3GPP 29.328 and</p><p>29.329. The base protocol used on this interface is Diameter as defined in RFC 3588. Both TCP and SCTP transport are supported for this interface. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>This interface is used by CTAS to retrieve information from the UDR/HSS for call routing logic for re- direction of a call from CS to IMS and for retrieving service data. The following Sh data reference values are supported in the Sh UDR commands in this release:</p><ul><li>IMSUserState (data reference 11)</li></ul><p>This query is used to retrieve the subscriber’s registration state in the IMS network while processing a CAP IDP for re-direction of a call from CS domain to IMS.</p><ul><li>Repository Data (data reference 0)</li></ul><p>This data reference is for retrieving service data attached to the user stored in the HSS.</p><p>Refer to the CTAS Sh Interface specification <a href="#_bookmark37">[50] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.6 Interface: CTAS to HLR"></a><a id="_bookmark75"></a><a id="_bookmark75"></a>Interface: CTAS to HLR</h3><p>CTAS supports a 3GPP-compliant MAP interface supporting version 1, 2 &amp; 3 to the HLR as defined in 3GPP 29.002. CTAS also supports ANSI-41 interface to the CDMA HLR. M3UA/SCTP transport is supported on this interface. This interface supports IPv4 only.</p><p>This MAP interface is used for supporting mobile-originated USSD strings received via IMS. CTAS also supports the ability to pass a USSD string received from the HLR back to the IMS UE. Refer to the USSD Use Case <a href="#_bookmark18">[29] </a>document for more details.</p><p>MAP interface is used for retrieving MSRN from HLR using MAP SRI query, for routing the call to CS domain in case of CS breakout or CS retry.</p><p>MAP Interface is also used for providing Location Based Services by supporting MAP SRI-LCS, MAP ATI and MAP PSL.</p><p>ANSI-41 interface to CDMA HLR is used for generating LOCREQ request.</p><h3><a id="6.1.7 Interface: CTAS to UDR"></a><a id="_bookmark76"></a><a id="_bookmark76"></a>Interface: CTAS to UDR</h3><h4><a id="6.1.7.1 LDAP Interface"></a><a id="_bookmark77"></a><a id="_bookmark77"></a>LDAP Interface</h4><p>CTAS supports an LDAP interface to the UDR for the following purposes:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>To retrieve the “MMTel” service profile of the subscriber. This profile identifies all supplementary services configured against the subscriber.</li><li>To retrieve or refresh the configuration data related to O-CSI and T-CSI elements which is also called the non-subscriber related (NSR) data associated with the “MMTel” service profile of the subscriber.</li><li>To retrieve or refresh the configuration data related Operator Configurable Control Data configured in a LDAP DS which may or may not be the same DS where subscriber data is stored. This is also referred to as non-subscriber related (NSR) data.</li><li>To update the “MMTel” service profile of the subscriber, based upon supplementary configuration commands received by the IMS UE via the Ut interface.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>This interface supports IPv4 only.</p><h4><a id="6.1.7.2 SOAP Interface"></a><a id="_bookmark78"></a><a id="_bookmark78"></a>SOAP Interface</h4><p>CTAS supports a SOAP interface via HTTP or HTTPS to the UDR for receiving notifications of changes to the “MMTel” service profile of the subscriber and the non-subscriber related data (CSI Data and OCCD). These SOAP triggers are generated by provisioning changes made at the UDR. The SOAP trigger is sent to all CTAS nodes in the network and acted upon only by the CTAS node which is active serving the subscriber.</p><p>This interface supports IPv4 only.</p><h4><a id="6.1.7.3 SPML Interface"></a><a id="_bookmark79"></a><a id="_bookmark79"></a>SPML Interface</h4><p>CTAS supports a SPML interface on SOAP via HTTP to the UDR for service configuration of the changes done by the user over Ut interface. Here is a complete list of SPML requests that are supported by the CTAS:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>searchRequest – This request is used to retrieve the identifier corresponding to the IMSI alias which must be used in the modifyRequest to perform modification.</li><li>modifyRequest – This request is used to modify the service data. CTAS supports following different versions over the SPML interface:</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><ol><li>SUBSCRIBER_v10</li></ol><p>SPML Interface targetNamespace = urn:siemens:names:prov:gw:SPML:2:0 Subscriber Data targetNamespace = urn:siemens:names:prov:gw:SUBSCRIBER:1:0 Request Version String = SUBSCRIBER_v10</p><p>HLR Data component name = hlrData</p><ol><li>SUBSCRIBER_v20</li></ol><p>SPML Interface targetNamespace = urn:siemens:names:prov:gw:SPML:2:0 Subscriber Data targetNamespace = urn:siemens:names:prov:gw:SUBSCRIBER:2:0 Request Version String = SUBSCRIBER_v20</p><p>HLR Data component name = HLR</p><ol><li>xx_SUBSCRIBER_v10, where xx is operator specific.</li></ol><p>SPML Interface targetNamespace = urn:siemens:names:prov:gw:SPML:2:0 Subscriber Data targetNamespace = urn:siemens:names:prov:gw:&lt;custom&gt; Request Version String = &lt;custom&gt;</p><p>The following are the list of supplementary services which can be modified over the SPML interface:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>CLIP/OIP</li><li>CLIR/OIR</li><li>COLP/TIP</li><li>COLR/TIR</li><li>CFU (unconditional)</li><li>CFB (busy)</li><li>CFNRc (not reachable)</li><li>CFNRy (no reply)</li><li>CW (Call Waiting)</li><li>BAOC (Barring of All Outgoing Calls)</li><li>BOIC (Barring of all Outgoing International Calls)</li><li>BOICExHC (Barring of all Outgoing International Calls except to the Home Country)</li><li>BAIC (Barring All Incoming Calls)</li><li>ALLCCF (All Conditional Call Forwarding) This interface supports IPv4 only.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h4><a id="6.1.7.4 Sh Interface"></a><a id="_bookmark80"></a><a id="_bookmark80"></a>Sh Interface</h4><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Sh interface to the IMS HSS FE as defined in 3GPP 29.328 and</p><p>29.329. The base protocol used on this interface is Diameter as defined in RFC 3588. Both TCP and SCTP transport are supported for this interface. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>This interface is used to retrieve and update the services data stored as transparent or non-transparent data.</p><p>Following are the list of XML document and the corresponding Services element supported over this interface:</p><ul><li>MMTEL-Services<ul><li>Originating Identification Presentation (OIP)</li><li>Originating Identification Restriction (OIR)</li><li>Terminating Identification Presentation (TIP)</li><li>Terminating Identification Restriction (TIR)</li><li>Communication DIVersion (CDIV)</li><li>Communication Waiting (CW)</li><li>Communication HOLD (HOLD)</li><li>Communication Barring (CB)</li><li>Completion of Communications to Busy Subscriber (CCBS)</li><li>CONFerence (CONF)</li></ul></li><li>IMS-ODB-Information<ul><li>Incoming Barring</li><li>Outgoing Barring</li><li>Outgoing Premium Call Barring</li><li>Operator Specific Barring</li></ul></li><li>IMS-CAMEL-Services<ul><li>O-IM-CSI</li><li>VT-IM-CSI</li></ul></li><li>Custom Extension - MMTEL-Custom-Services<ul><li>IMSI</li><li>Calling Name Presentation (CNAP)</li><li>Call Forwarding Default for Busy (CFDforCFB)</li><li>Call Forwarding Default for Not Reachable (CFDforCFNRc)</li><li>Call Forwarding Default for No Reply (CFDforCFNR)</li><li>Supplementary Service Code List (SSLIST, which include National Supplementary Services List)</li><li>TIF CSI</li></ul></li><li>Custom Extension - IMS-Services (for IMS services which does not have a corresponding HLR equivalent)<ul><li>Video</li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the CTAS Sh Interface specification <a href="#_bookmark37">[50] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.8 Interface: CTAS to IN SCP"></a><a id="_bookmark81"></a><a id="_bookmark81"></a>Interface: CTAS to IN SCP</h3><p>CTAS supports a CAP interface to the SCPs for providing IN services to IMS subscribers. CTAS supports CAP versions 2, 3 and 4 and INAP version CS1 and CS2 on this interface. M3UA/SCTP transport is supported on this interface. This interface supports IPv4 only.</p><p>Refer to the CTAS IN Interworking Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark26">[37], </a>and the Mavenir VoLTE Standards Compliance document <a href="#_bookmark4">[1] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.9 Interface: CTAS to CDF"></a><a id="_bookmark82"></a><a id="_bookmark82"></a>Interface: CTAS to CDF</h3><p>CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Rf interface to the CDF as defined in 3GPP 32.299. The base protocol used on this interface is Diameter as defined in RFC 3588. Both TCP and SCTP transport are supported for this interface. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>This interface is used to report offline charging events to the CDF for CDR generation. Specifically:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Session-based charging is used to report on successfully answered call legs</li><li>Event-based charging is used to report on:<ul><li>Unsuccessful call setup attempts</li><li>Subscriber controlled input, e.g. service configuration changes made via the Ut interface or via user dialed feature codes</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the Rf Interface Specification document <a href="#_bookmark27">[38] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.10 Interface: CTAS to MRF"></a><a id="_bookmark83"></a><a id="_bookmark83"></a>Interface: CTAS to MRF</h3><p>CTAS supports a Mr’ interface with the MRF. The Mr’ interface directly connects the CTAS and MRF, this signaling does not traverse the S-CSCF. The Mr’ interface is realized using the SIP and MSML (RFC 5707) protocols.</p><p>This interface is used by CTAS for all functions which require access to media, such as:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Playing tones or announcements</li><li>Establishing conferences for the 3GPP MMTel CONF/3PTY service</li><li>DTMF prompt &amp; collect functions as required for IN services</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the MRF Interface Specification document <a href="#_bookmark28">[39] </a>and MRF Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark29">[40] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.11 Interface: CTAS to AMDF"></a><a id="_bookmark84"></a><a id="_bookmark84"></a>Interface: CTAS to AMDF</h3><p>CTAS supports an X1 interface to the AMDF component of the LIMS for administration purposes. The X1 interface is used to manage the provisioned LI targets on the CTAS.</p><p>The protocol used on X1 is SOAP over HTTPS. This interface supports IPv4 only. Refer to the LI Interfaces Mavenir Application Server document <a href="#_bookmark30">[41] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.12 Interface: CTAS to DF2"></a><a id="_bookmark85"></a><a id="_bookmark85"></a>Interface: CTAS to DF2</h3><p>CTAS supports an X2 interface to the DF2 component of the LIMS to send Interception Related Information (IRI), e.g. signaling events. CTAS uses the X2 interface to report the following IRI to the DF2:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Conferencing events</li><li>Subscriber Controlled Input (SCI) events, e.g. Ut requests or via user dialed feature codes to change supplementary service data</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The protocol stack used on the X2 interface is:</p><table><tr><td><p>XML</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>X2TP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TCP</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TLS</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>IP</p></td></tr></table><p>X2TP is the X2 Transfer Protocol, a simple proprietary protocol used to relay X2 information. This interface supports IPv4 only.</p><p>Refer to the CTAS LI Interfaces Description document <a href="#_bookmark30">[41] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.13 Interface: CTAS to iDNS"></a><a id="_bookmark86"></a><a id="_bookmark86"></a>Interface: CTAS to iDNS</h3><p>CTAS supports a DNS interface to the customer iDNS for address resolution purposes. CTAS supports NAPTR, SRV, A and (for some interfaces) AAA records.</p><p>For SIP interfaces, the CTAS supports RFC 3263.</p><h3><a id="6.1.14 Interface: CTAS to ENUM"></a><a id="_bookmark87"></a><a id="_bookmark87"></a>Interface: CTAS to ENUM</h3><p>CTAS supports an ENUM interface to ENUM Front End Service implemented as a Number Portability system. In addition it also support ENUM interface to query for SPID and LRN.</p><p>Refer to the ENUM Interface specification document <a href="#_bookmark38">[51] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="6.1.15 Interface: CTAS to OCF"></a><a id="_bookmark88"></a><a id="_bookmark88"></a>Interface: CTAS to OCF</h3><p>The CTAS supports the 3GPP-defined Ro interface to the OCF (Online Charging Functionality within Online Charging Server (OCS)) as defined defined in 3GPP TS 32.299 <a href="#_bookmark6">[10], </a>3GPP TS 32.260 <a href="#_bookmark33">[45], </a>with MMTel extensions defined in 3GPP TS 32.275 <a href="#_bookmark34">[46] </a>and Mavenir extension as defined in CTAS Ro interface specification <a href="#_bookmark31">[43].</a></p><p>The base protocol used on this interface is DIAMETER as defined in IETF RFC 3588 <a href="#_bookmark5">[7] </a>and IETF RFC 4006 <a href="#_bookmark32">[44].</a> Both TCP and SCTP transport are supported for this interface. This interface supports IPv4 and IPv6.</p><p>Refer to the Ro Interface Specification document <a href="#_bookmark31">[43] </a>for more details on the scenarios supported and a list of supported AVPs.</p><h3><a id="6.1.16 Interface: CTAS to GLS"></a><a id="_bookmark89"></a><a id="_bookmark89"></a>Interface: CTAS to GLS</h3><p>CTAS supports a SOAP (client) Interface to Geo Location Server to retrieve the Location Information corresponding to the Public UE IP. The UE IP is received as the child element of the &lt;ims-3gpp&gt; XML element included in the Third-Party REGISTER. The S-CSCF inserts this UE IP after taking it from the via header of the UE REGISTER.</p><p>This interface is invoked when the user is registered on WiFi Access.</p><h3><a id="6.1.17 Interface: CTAS to iHLR"></a><a id="_bookmark90"></a><a id="_bookmark90"></a>Interface: CTAS to iHLR</h3><p>CTAS supports a SOAP (server) Interface to the iHLR node, which is used to query for locally cached subscriber information. This interface is mainly used for debugging purpose and currently supports returning IMPU, Registration status, Latitude/Longitude, CTAS GT Address, CGI, etc.</p><h3><a id="6.1.18 Interface: CTAS to SDM"></a><a id="_bookmark91"></a><a id="_bookmark91"></a>Interface: CTAS to SDM</h3><p>CTAS supports a SIP Interface to the SDM node, which is used to maintain the IMS Registration state for the user. When Initial Registration request is received at the CTAS for MMTEL Voice, the CTAS generates a 4th Party REGISTER to the SDM, which will create an entry and store the CTAS GT address corresponding to the CTAS FQDN received in the REGISER request. This information is looked up from the CS domain for CS origination call routing to determine, if the terminating user is IMS Registered or not. If the user is found to be IMS Registered (i.e. entry exists in the SDM), the call is routed to the IMS domain.</p><p>The CTAS GT address stored is used to route MAP SRI-LCS request to the CTAS node anchoring the subscriber. Saving of the CTAS GT address is operator specific.</p><p>The SDM entry is removed, when the user does a De-REGISTER or the profile is removed the CTAS.</p><h3><a id="6.1.19 Interface: CTAS to CNAM DB"></a><a id="_bookmark92"></a><a id="_bookmark92"></a>Interface: CTAS to CNAM DB</h3><p>CTAS supports a TCAP interface to the CNAM Db to query for the Calling Name of the originating user to be delivered to the Called Party if the called party has subscribed to the CNAM feature.</p><h3><a id="6.1.20 Interface: CTAS to IN SSF"></a><a id="_bookmark93"></a><a id="_bookmark93"></a>Interface: CTAS to IN SSF</h3><p>CTAS comprises of an integrated SCP (iSCP) which supports CAP v2, v3, INAP CS-1 and CS-2, and ANSI-41 Ver E protocols. The main purpose of the iSCP is for redirection of calls terminated in CS domain to IMS over ICS Mg interface.</p><p>M3UA/SCTP transport is supported on this interface. This interface supports IPv4 only.</p><h3><a id="6.1.21 Interface: CTAS to DND DB"></a><a id="_bookmark94"></a><a id="_bookmark94"></a>Interface: CTAS to DND DB</h3><p>CTAS supports a Sh interface to the DND Db to query for Called Party subscriber’s DND subscription.</p><h3><a id="6.1.22 Interface: CTAS to CCPS"></a><a id="_bookmark95"></a><a id="_bookmark95"></a>Interface: CTAS to CCPS</h3><p>CTAS supports a SOAP (client) Interface to the CCPS node to set appropriate T-CSI Service information in the subscriber profile in the UDR. This interface is invoked when the user is registered using LTE access and the type of T-CSI identified in the subscriber profile is not LTE.</p><h3><a id="6.1.23 Interface: Summary"></a><a id="_bookmark96"></a><a id="_bookmark96"></a>Interface: Summary</h3><p>The table below summarizes the Transport support for each of the On failure to route the request to the CSCF, the request is reattempted to the same node as per the SIP Timer configuration and on failure of all reattempts, the request is rejected.</p></td></tr></table><h2><a id="6.2 Overall OSS Architecture"></a><a id="_bookmark97"></a><a id="_bookmark97"></a>Overall OSS Architecture</h2><p>The following diagram depicts the CTAS and Centralized Management System (CMS) interfaces required to achieve the FCAPS functionality defined within this document, specifically for Accounting Management (AM), Fault Management (FM), Performance Management (PM) and Configuration Management (CM).</p><p>Note: CMS is an optional Management node in the Network. All interfaces from CTAS to CMS will be from CTAS to OSS when CMS is not part of the Network architecture.</p><p>(S)FTP</p><p>CAP</p><p>R</p><p>SNMP\t(S)FTP</p><p>HTTP(S)/XML</p><p><strong>TAS</strong></p><p>EMS</p><p>CM</p><p>PM</p><p>FM</p><p>AM</p><p>Ro</p><p>f</p><p>OSS</p><p>OCF</p><p>CCF</p><p>SCP</p><p><strong>CMS</strong></p><p>The following table summarizes the CTAS FCAPS interfaces towards CMS and OSS in this release.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Peer Node/System</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Application Protocol</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Locality</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CMS</p></td><td><p>HTTP(S)/XML</p></td><td><p>National</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OSS</p></td><td><p>(S)FTP SNMP</p></td><td><p>National</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="6.2.1 Interface: CTAS to CMS"></a><a id="_bookmark98"></a><a id="_bookmark98"></a>Interface: CTAS to CMS</h3><h4><a id="6.2.1.1 Configuration Management (CM) In"></a><a id="_bookmark99"></a>6.2.1.1\tConfiguration Management (CM) Interface</h4><p>For common CTAS tables configured on CMS, CMS supports an HTTP(S)/XML interface with CTAS for the transfer of this configuration data to each CTAS system. CMS owns the master copy of these tables and ensures that each CTAS system remains synchronized.</p><p>For CTAS tables which are specific to each CTAS system, CMS runs a SGD Server which provides a jump station for access to each CTAS system. This allows external clients to access the CTAS EMS via CMS.</p><h3><a id="6.2.2 Interface: CTAS to OSS"></a><a id="_bookmark100"></a><a id="_bookmark100"></a>Interface: CTAS to OSS</h3><h4><a id="6.2.2.1 Performance Management (PM) Inte"></a><a id="_bookmark101"></a><a id="_bookmark101"></a>Performance Management (PM) Interface</h4><p>CTAS supports an (S)FTP interface with OSS which is used to retrieve Performance Management (PM) data.</p><p>CTAS collects statistical data in the form of performance counters and writes this data into CSV files at period intervals, configurable between 5 and 15 minutes. OSS then retrieves these CSV files from each CTAS system via (S)FTP at periodic intervals.</p><h4><a id="6.2.2.2 Fault Management (FM) Interface"></a><a id="_bookmark102"></a><a id="_bookmark102"></a>Fault Management (FM) Interface</h4><p>CTAS supports an SNMP interface to OSS for reporting events and alarms. CTAS supports SNMP versions 1, 2c and 3. This MIB used on this interface will be provided separately.</p><h1><a id="7 Functional Description"></a><a id="_bookmark103"></a><a id="_bookmark103"></a>Functional Description</h1><p>While the main functional use cases are described at a high level in the subsequent sections, further details can be found in the separate CTAS Use Case documents which exist. These include the following:</p><ul><li>MMTEL User Profile Use Cases– This document describes CTAS uses cases related to managing the user profile which is stored in the UDR.</li><li>USSI Use Cases <a href="#_bookmark18">[29] </a>– This document describes CTAS use cases related to mobile initiated USSI requests.</li><li>Multi-SIM Use Cases <a href="#_bookmark20">[31] </a>– This document describes CTAS handling of Multi-SIM subscribers for various services and functions.</li><li>Ut Interface Use Cases <a href="#_bookmark21">[32] </a>– This document describes CTAS use cases as they relate to the 3GPP defined Ut interface.</li><li>Announcements / Tones Use Cases <a href="#_bookmark22">[33] </a>– This document describes CTAS support for tones and announcements.</li><li>RBT Use Cases <a href="#_bookmark23">[34] </a>– This document describes CTAS support for the Ring Back Tone (RBT) service.</li><li>CDIV Use Cases<a href="#_bookmark24">[35] </a>– This document describes CTAS support for the Communication Diversion (i.e. call forwarding) supplementary service.</li><li>Availability and Recovery Use Cases – This document describes use cases related to CTAS hardware and software failures and recovery.</li></ul><p>The details and call flows in these Use Case documents are not repeated in this document.</p><p>Furthermore, details of the CTAS’s internal IM-SSF function are not covered in this document but can instead be found in the IM-SSF System Specification document <strong>Error! Reference source not found.</strong>.</p><h2><a id="7.1 Registration and User Profile"></a><a id="_bookmark104"></a><a id="_bookmark104"></a>Registration and User Profile</h2><p>The CTAS supports 3rd party initial, refresh and de-registration of subscribers by the S-CSCF.</p><p>Some of the high level procedures involved in the initial registration at CTAS are defined below, for more details refer to the User Profile Use Case document<strong>Error! Reference source not found.</strong>.</p><ul><li>Creating registration data using the information received in the UE REGISTER request and response embedded in the 3rd party REGISTER request. The contact binding is done on the basis of the Contact URI and the Instance-Id identified by the “+sip.instance” media feature tag included in the Contact header field parameter. All relevant information received is stored as part of the Contact binding.</li><li>Creating the user profile by retrieving the subscriber and non-subscriber related data from the UDR/HSS and caching it locally. Note that the non-subscriber related data is cached separately, separate from the subscriber data.</li></ul><p>Some of the high level procedures involved in the refresh registration at CTAS are defined below, for more details refer to the User Profile Use Case document.</p><ul><li>Update the contact bindings with the information received in the 3rd party REGISTER request. The refresh 3rd party REGISTER may be triggered due to an initial UE REGISTER for another device which is part of the same implicit registration set, hence the CTAS may have to create a new contact binding for the IMPU.</li><li>Reset the reg-timer</li></ul><p>Some of the high level procedures involved in the de-registration at CTAS are defined below, for more details refer to the User Profile Use Case document.</p><ul><li>Remove the contact binding for the device deregistering, the device identified by the IMPI.</li><li>If this is the last device being deregistered, the user profile is marked as deregistered, and will be removed when the inactivity timer expires.</li></ul><p>As part of the user profile management, the CTAS will support SOAP triggers as a subscriber data change notification from the UDR. This change notification is triggered due to any changes done from the backend by Operations on the subscriber data.</p><h3><a id="7.1.1 Relationship of Private and Public"></a><a id="_bookmark105"></a><a id="_bookmark105"></a>Relationship of Private and Public Identifies with Contact Binding</h3><p>Here is the high level figure showing the relation between the Public User (np)</li><li>PVNI</li><li>VPLMN-ID</li><li>CGI</li><li>IMEI/IMEISV</li><li>ATCF Info</li></ul><p><strong>Registration Data</strong></p><p>Public User identities may be shared across multiple Private User Identities within the same IMS subscription. Hence, a particular Public User Identity may be simultaneously registered from multiple UEs that use different Private User Identities and different contact addresses.</p><p>The User profile comprises of the Services data which is downloaded from the HSS during the Initial Registration procedure. Only one user profile is associated with the Implicit Registration Set (IRS). This services data may also include device specific data, where the device is identified by the IMSI. The contact binding will be maintained on per device basis, where the device is identified by the instance-id received in the contact header of the REGISTER request.</p><p>A single device or single SIM subscriber can register multiple UA instances and each such UA instance can register using the same or different IMPI. The Instance-Id is expected to be unique across all the contact binding for a particular IMPU and this instance-id will be used to identify a particular contact binding. For example, when an origination received from a particular instance, the instance id received in the Contact header field will be used to identify the originating device instance. If Instance-Id is not received in the Contact header field (as it is not mandatory for the client to include instance-id in the Contact header field), there is need for another mechanism to identify the originating instance. Proxy- Authorization header containing IMPI is one such header which may be included by the S-CSCF which will be used to identify the instance when instance-id is not included. The use of Proxy-Authorization header imposes a limitation on identifying the contact binding. If there are more than one contact binding registered against a particular IMPI, it is not possible to identify the contact binding with just the IMPI, and therefore where there is a possibility of registering multiple instances using the same IMPI, the instance-id MUST be included in the Contact header of the INVITE request.</p><h3><a id="7.1.2 Registration Flow"></a><a id="_bookmark106"></a><a Data</li><li>T-CSI</li><li>O-CSI</li><li>Other Operator Specific Data</li></ul><h2><a id="7.2 Call Establishment and Termination"></a><a id="_bookmark107"></a><a id="_bookmark107"></a>Call Establishment and Termination</h2><p>The Call Establishment at CTAS is broken up into multiple phases, which are common across origination and termination:</p><ul><li>Profile Retrieval and Validation</li><li>Trigger Processing</li><li>Services</li><li>Translations</li><li>Call Routing</li></ul><h3><a id="7.2.1 Basic Call Processing"></a><a id="_bookmark108"></a><a id="_bookmark108"></a>Basic Call Processing</h3><h4><a id="7.2.1.1 Call Origination at MMTEL"></a><a id="_bookmark109"></a><a id="_bookmark109"></a>Call Origination at MMTEL</h4><p>The figure below shows the sequence followed while processing the MMTEL call origination request. Based on the iFC configuration, the S-CSCF routes the call origination request to the CTAS. SCC AS being the integrated node is going to be the first application to be invoked. The SCC AS in the origination path will anchor the call leg and internally route the request to the MMTEL application.</p><p>The call processing procedures at the MMTEL involves applying one or more translation and screening profiles are various stages of the call processing. Every one of these profiles will have specific rules configured and the action configured in the matching rule will determine the next course of action to be taken. Refer to the Translation Functional Description document for the function of each of the pre- defined translation and screening profiles.</p><p>The Application Config (APPCFG) rules will determine the integrated sub-application to be invoked, which will be MMTEL by default. It will also set various SKIP flags which will control the invocation of Supplementary and other services.</p><p>Before allowing call processing to continue for call origination, the MMTEL performs profile retrieval and validation. Prior to Profile Retrieval, the Pre-Translator (PRTCT) profile is applied to normalize the calling and the called party number. The normalized calling and called party number will be used in all subsequent call processing procedures.</p><p>The Service Screening (SVCSCR) rules will screen the call origination request for defining service specific conditions and restriction. This profile sets the ACCESSCLASS based on the P-Access-Network- Info header received, which will be used for pegging access specific KPIs.</p><p>The Translation (TRN) rules may be used for number modification or for identifying specific dialed patter to identify specific service request such as Conference Creation, USSD Request, User Config (SIP based) Request, etc. When USSD or User Config service request is identified, a specific Feature (FEAT) profile is invoked to further analyze the dial string. If the dial string matches a configured USSD string, the call control is passed on to the integrated USSD AS for USSD request processing. Refer to Section <a href="#_bookmark152">7.5.3</a> for more details. If the dial string matches a configured Feature code, the User config request is processing and UDR is updated. Refer to User Profile UC <a href="#_bookmark42">[55] </a>or <a href="#_bookmark41">[54] </a>for more details.</p><p>Prior to applying Call Barring (CB) or Operator Determined Barring (ODB) as defined in Section <a href="#_bookmark136">7.4.6 </a>and Section <a href="#_bookmark137">7.4.7, </a>the MMTEL will invoke Roam Analyzer (ROAMANZ) rules to determine the roaming status of the user. The roaming status is determined using the VLR address allocated for the served originating user. The VLR Address is identified based on the P-Visited-Network-Id header received in the Initial INVITE or the previous registration.</p><p>If the origination request is not barred, the Call Analyzer (CALLANZ) rules are applied to determine the type of call being originated. The type of call could be International, Premium rate, etc, which is used for applying specific types of barring at the later stage of the call. This analysis is done prior to any ENUM or IN trigger invocation which may possibly modify the called party number. It could also be possible to apply this call analysis much later in the call processing.</p><p>The ENUM trigger for MNP check is configured to be invoked at one or more stages of the call. Whether the ENUM is invoked at the configured stage is determined by the SKIP_ENUM flag set by the preceding translation &amp; screening profile. Default value of SKIP_ENUM flag is False, translation rules can explicitly disable ENUM trigger by setting this flag to True. For example, ENUM need not be triggered for International calls, which can be ensured by setting SKIP_ENUM=TRUE when CALLTYPE = INTL. Refer to Section <a href="#_bookmark114">7.2.4.</a></p><p>The MMTEL supports Integrated IM-SSF, which will be support invoking IN Trigger based on active O- CSI and/or one or more N-CSI triggers. Refer to IM-SSF IN-IW Use Cases <a href="#_bookmark26">[37] </a>for more details. The Integrated IM-SSF may also be skipped using the SKIP_INAP and SKIP_CAP flags.</p><p>The Dialed Number Translation (DNTRN) table is tabular based number manipulation framework mainly used for converting short codes to long codes, which could also be used for other number manipulation. This number manipulation can be configured based on one or more input criteria. ENUM trigger configured to be invoked following DNTRN, which may be used to trigger ENUM for the modified called party number.</p><p>Ro based Charging trigger is configured to be invoked just before call routing. This can be skipped for special numbers by setting SKIP_Ro flags in preceding translations. For example, if Ro based online charging need not be invoked for certain short codes, it is possible to set SKIP_Ro flag for matching short codes.</p><p>Prior to routing the call, the final screening (SCR) profile is applied which is used to apply Operator Determined Barring Type 1-4 and also to re-write the Request-URI based on the routing number returned in ENUM response or from the SCP. Based on the routing number returned the called party number in the Request-URI may need to be reformatted to include “rn” and “npdi”. Following the SCR profile, the MMTEL will apply CB/ODB and if the call is not barred, the call is routed to the S-CSCF.</p><p>From SCC</p><p>INVITE</p><p>PRTCT</p><p>APPCFG</p><p>(orig)</p><p>Profile Retrieval and Validation</p><img src="data:image/png;base64," /><p>USSD</p><p>SVCSCR</p><p><strong>SVCAUSE</strong></p><p>FEAT</p><p>TRN</p><p><strong>=FEAT</strong></p><p><strong>SVCCAUSE = id="7.2.1.2 Call Termination at MMTEL"></a><a id="_bookmark110"></a><a id="_bookmark110"></a>Call Termination at MMTEL</h4><p>The figure below shows the sequence followed while processing the MMTEL call termination request. Based on the iFC configuration, the S-CSCF routes the call termination request to the CTAS. By default MMTEL will be the first application to process the call termination request. Following which the request is routed to the integrated SCC AS.</p><p>Similar to the call origination request, multiple translations and screening profiles are applied at various staged of the call termination processing, which will control services invoked as part of the termination processing.</p><p>If the call termination request is to an unregistered user, the MMTEL will retrieve the user profile from the UDR and if enabled will retrieve the latest CS Location Information from the HSS. The VLR number retrieved from the HSS will be used as the input to Roam Analyzer (ROAMANZ) to determine Roaming Status. This procedure of retrieving the user profile and CS Location Information is done as part of Profile Retrieval.</p><p>After applying all the term services, if the call is not barred, the call termination request is routed to the SCC AS.</p><img src="data:image/png;base64," /><img src="data:image/png;base64," /><img src="data:image/png;base64," /><img src="data:image/png;base64," /><img Call rejected by sending configurable SIP error response.</p><h4><a id="7.2.1.3 Call Termination at SCC"></a><a id="_bookmark111"></a><a id="_bookmark111"></a>Call Termination at SCC</h4><p>The figure below defines the different points in call terminations where the Translation profiles are executed at the integrated SCC AS.</p><p>The processes defined in the below procedure flow are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Process T-ADS &amp; Domain Selection; Refer to Section <strong>Error!
