OR tel:+&lt;CSRN&gt; - When MS ISDN is presen in the user part, the “CS breakout prefix” is needed to ensure the term iFC is</p><p>stopped, which happens when the SCSCF detects a difference in the incoming Request-URI compared to what is sent in the outgoing direct ion</p><p><strong>Return Error Response to</strong></p><p><strong>MMTEL</strong></p><p><strong>Yes</strong></p><img src="data:image/png;base64," /><table><tr><td></td><td><p>Session</p><p>Anchored</p></td><td></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.2.2 Profile Retrieval and Validation"></a><a id="_bookmark112"></a><a id="_bookmark112"></a>Profile Retrieval and Validation</h3><p>When the CTAS receives an origination or termination request, the served user’s user profile is retrieved from the local cache. If the served user’s user profile is not available in the local cache, the profile is recovered from the UDR before proceeding with the call processing.</p><p>Following a successful retrieval of the served user’s user profile, the CTAS performs some basic validation to ensure that the subscriber originating the call is in good standing based on the profile information received. As part of this validation procedure, the following checks are applied:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>MMTel security level check – If the served user accessing MMTel service has not been authenticated using AKA authentication scheme, the call origination is not allowed; The MMTel security level check is controlled using system wide configuration and can be disabled.</li><li>Device check – If the terminal identity (IMSI) of the originating device is not considered to be registered i.e. not part of the contact binding stored in the user profile, the call origination is not allowed.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>When the profile retrieval and validation is complete, the call processing continues. If the profile validation for call origination or termination fails, the call origination or termination request is disallowed.</p><p>If the profile retrieval of the served originating or terminating user’s user profile fails for some reason or the UDR is not available (test lab only), the CTAS supports a provision to using a locally configured default subscriber profile. The default subscriber profile is a configurable user profile containing attributes for services similar to that which is available for configuration in the UDR.</p><p>For more details on profile retrieval, refer to the CTAS MMTel User Profile use case document <a href="#_bookmark41">[54] </a>or <a href="#_bookmark42">[55].</a></p><h3><a id="7.2.3 Trigger Processing"></a><a id="_bookmark113"></a><a id="_bookmark113"></a>Trigger Processing</h3><p>The gsmSSF or IM-SSF module of the CTAS supports subscriber-based IN triggers to accommodate subscriber services provided by the SCP platforms in the network. These triggers are checked after successfully completing the profile retrieval and validation. In many instances, the service results in new destination address being returned from the SCP that are intended to route the call to a specific terminating point. The SCP may also perform translation or correct the destination address for number portability. The information provided by the SCP is eventually mapped to appropriate headers and used for routing of the INVITE request.</p><p>In addition to subscriber-based triggers, the CTAS also supports office-based triggers. The office-based triggers are configurable by the operator in the CTAS to fire when a specified digit pattern is detected.</p><p>Based on the provisioning, the CTAS examines the dialed digit string to determine whether an office- based trigger match occurs. If a match occurs, the IN trigger is fired and the call processing continues based on the instruction received from the SCP. The SCP may possibly return new address digits. This new set of destination address is checked for office-based trigger matching and may cause a trigger to be invoked. In this way, there can potentially be a number of passes through the office-based trigger cycle for a single call.</p><p>The SCP invoked due to subscriber-based IN trigger or office-based IN trigger may invoke user interaction with the calling party by sending instructions to play announcement or prompt and collect. These instructions are processed by the gsmSRF module of the CTAS and will invoke the MRF to provide the necessary user interaction.</p><p>The final destination address received from the last SCP invoked is used for routing the INVITE request. Refer to the IN Interworking Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark26">[37] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="7.2.4 MNP Check"></a><a id="_bookmark114"></a><a id="_bookmark114"></a>MNP Check</h3><p>Mobile Number Portability (NP) check is performed as part of the origination session to determine the destination network of the recipient. The MNP procedure is to be applied for each session that is initiated by the served originating user. There could be exceptions configured at the TAS for certain special numbers, short codes or for international dialing.</p><p>The NP related information is stored in NPDB within the operator’s network. The MNP procedures are realized using any of the below supported mechanisms::</p><ul><li>CAP v2 based MNP Query</li><li>INAP CS-2 based MNP Query</li><li>ENUM based MNP Query</li></ul><p>The CAP based MNP Query is triggered based on the O-CSI subscription of the served user, while the INAP based MNP Query is done based on office based trigger for dialed number. The IN SCP might return a NIP (Number Portability Information) which identifies different routing to be used for a particular session. The NIP is used to build the outgoing Request-URI which might include “npdi” and “rn” parameter.</p><p>The ENUM based MNP Query can be configured to be performed at various stages of the origination sessions based on service logic. For example, for certain numbers the MNP check must be performed before the IN Triggering, such that the IN SCP is aware of the portability status of the called party number. For certain special numbers, the MNP check must be performed after the number has been modified. Therefore the MNP trigger is checked at various Point In Calls, and if armed and if the Skip ENUM flag has not been set by the preceding translation rule, the ENUM is triggered for the called party address.</p><p>As part of the MNP check, the CTAS will trigger an ENUM query and will update the original Request-URI with the URI returned in the ENUM Response. All subsequent call processing will use the possibly modified called party address returned by the ENUM server. The ENUM response returned might include “rn” and “npdi”, or may just return a NIP indicator, which may or may not be translated by the CTAS into a specific Request-URI format.</p><h3><a id="7.2.5 DND Check"></a><a id="_bookmark115"></a><a id="_bookmark115"></a>DND Check</h3><p>The Do Not Disturb (DND) service enables a user to avoid receiving unwanted telemarketing calls by registration of their telephone number in the National Do Not Call register.</p><p>The access provider will maintain a local DND DB which will be synced with the National Do Not Call register periodically. The CTAS will interface to the DND DB using the Sh (Diameter) Interface. For every call from the calling party pattern that matches a telemarketer, the CTAS will generate a DND query to the local DND DB over the Sh interface using the normalized Called Party MSISDN. The CTAS rejects the call if an entry for the particular subscriber is present in the database, otherwise the call is continued to the subscriber.</p><h3><a id="7.2.6 Video Calling"></a><a id="_bookmark116"></a><a id="_bookmark116"></a>Video Calling</h3><p>The Video Calling support at the CTAS enables users to make conversational video calls with full-duplex voice and video streams. The Video calling service support is based on the limited capabilities defined in the GSMA IR.94 PRD. Users can make one to one video call, switch to video at any point in call and drop video at any point in call while continuing with voice.</p><p>Below is the high level summary of the Video Calling support at the CTAS:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Compliance to IR.94 v5.0 (conversational video), relevant sections which are supported at the CTAS are:<ul><li>Section 2.2.1 SIP Registration procedures</li><li>Section 2.2.2 Call Establishment and Termination [NOTE : the SDP negotiation remains transparent to the TAS]</li><li>Section 2.3 Early Media</li><li>Section 2.3 Supplementary Services</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>All IR.92 defined SS are supported for video as well.</p><p>Section 2.3.2 Hold</p><p>Section 2.3.3 Ad-Hoc Multi Party Conference</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>SRVCC for Video session is not supported, only the audio component is transferred and video component is rejected.</li></ul></li><li>SS data specific for Video<ul><li>No support for video specific SS received over LDAP Interface. In such case, all audio SS will be applied for Video session too.</li><li>Supports video specific SS received over Sh interface, which is based on standard defined MMTEL-Services XML in 29.364. This enables configuration of Video specific CDIV and Video specific CB.</li></ul></li><li>Other services are:<ul><li>Supports playing video announcement for video session, also supports network provided Video Local Ring Tone</li><li>Supports Ro interface based online charging for Video sessions. No impact of Offline CDR/Rf charging, as it already captures SDP.</li><li>SIP based user config for Video CFx Activation/Deactivation (this is mainly for fixed terminals)</li></ul></li><li>Other miscellaneous items related to Video are:<ul><li>Video specific KPIs</li><li>Capability to perform session (audio or video) based flexible number translation</li><li>Capability to suppress or enable SS and other features based on Session Type (Audio or Video)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h3><a id="7.2.7 Services"></a><a id="_bookmark117"></a><a id="_bookmark117"></a>Services</h3><p>At various stages of call establishment and during the call, the originating or terminating supplementary services configured in the served user’s profile is applied. The services are described in detail in subsequent sections of this document.</p><h3><a id="7.2.8 Translations &amp; Screening"></a><a id="_bookmark118"></a><a id="_bookmark118"></a>Translations &amp; Screening</h3><p>Translations are applied at multiple phases of the call and every time serving a different purpose. Some of the translations are applied during basic call processing and some special translations rules are applied for services or special routing.</p><p>Refer to the CTAS Translations &amp; Screening Functional Description document <a href="#_bookmark25">[36] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="7.2.9 Call Routing"></a><a id="_bookmark119"></a><a id="_bookmark119"></a>Call Routing</h3><p>Since the CTAS node is not responsible for determining the destination route, all it does is to update the Request-URI with the final destination address. The final destination address may have been possibly modified by the SCP or the ENUM Server or it could be the original destination address. Depending on the services and features applied, the CTAS will use any of the ISC mode of operation i.e. routing B2BUA, initiating B2BUA or Originating UA to route the call.</p><h3><a id="7.2.10 Basic SBC</p><p>MSC/VLR</p><p>MGCF</p><p>BGCF</p><p>S-CSCF</p><p>I-CSCF</p><p>UDR</p><p>BGCF</p><p>S-CSCF</p><p>UE-1</p><p>UDR</p><p>IN SCP</p><p>UE2</p><p>NOTE: The diagram above assumes CTAS is configured for MAP SRI to be used for CSRN generation. This could also be modified to support Local CSRN generation or Sh query for CSRN.</p><h2><a id="7.3 Service Brokering (SB)"></a><a id="_bookmark125"></a><a id="_bookmark125"></a>Service Brokering (SB)</h2><p>The CTAS supports multiple integrated applications and functions, which are invoked in a predefined order for the purpose of establishing an MMTEL session. These integrated applications and functions can also be treated as independent applications and can be invoked independently or can be invoked in combination of one or more applications. The Service Broker facilitates the invocation of one or more integrated CTAS applications.</p><p>Service Broker</p><p>SCC\t<strong>….</strong></p><p>MMTEL</p><p><strong>….</strong></p><p>CTF</p><p>(Ro/Rf)</p><p>USSD</p><p>IM-SSF</p><p><strong>CTAS</strong></p><p>ISC\tMa</p><p>S-CSCF</p><p>I-CSCF</p><p>The SB functionality can be used to have external applications invoke a specific integrated application of the CTAS. Some of the use cases for using the SB are:</p><ul><li>The CTAS can be included in the signaling path of non-MMTEL voice session for the purpose of providing IN-IW function of the integrated IM-SSF.</li><li>The CTAS can be included in the signaling path of Videoshare session for the purpose of providing Online Charging (Ro) function of the integrated CTF.</li><li>The CTAS can be included in the signaling path of non-MMTEL voice session for the purpose of providing Session Continuity function of the integrated SCC AS,</li><li>Etc.</li></ul><h3><a id="7.3.1 Integrated Applications"></a><a id="_bookmark126"></a><a id="_bookmark126"></a>Integrated Applications</h3><p>The two main integrated applications supported at the CTAS are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>MMTEL – This is the default application providing MMTEL Supplementary Services.</li><li>SCC AS – This is the Session Centralization and Continuity Application Server providing Session anchoring, Session continuity in the form of PS to CS SRVCC and CS breakout/Retry functions.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The MMTEL sub-applications which can be invoked using the SB interaction logic are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>IM-SSF – Integrated gsmSSF &amp; gsmSRF providing IN Interworking</li><li>CTF for online charging via Ro Interface</li><li>USSD – MO USSD Service</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The SCC sub-functions which can be invoked using the SB interaction logic are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>CS breakout</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h3><a id="7.3.2 Supplementary Service Suppression"></a><a id="_bookmark127"></a><a id="_bookmark127"></a>Supplementary Service Suppression</h3><p>When the request is routed to the CTAS for the purpose of invoking IN Interworking function of the integrated IM-SSF or for invoking any other MMTEL sub-application, there will be a need to suppress the Supplementary Services supported by the MMTEL. This is achieved using the Translation and Service screening framework which allows defining rules to suppress Supplementary Services based on one or more input criteria (s).</p><p>The list of Supplementary Services which can be controlled using this mechanism are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>OIP (Originating Identity Presentation)</li><li>OIR (Originating Identity Restriction)</li><li>TIP (Terminating Identity Presentation)</li><li>TIR (Terminating Identity Restriction)</li><li>CFU (Communication Forwarding Unconditional)</li><li>CFB (Communication Forwarding on Busy user)</li><li>CFNR (Communication Forwarding on no Reply)</li><li>CFNRc (Communication Forwarding on Subscriber Not Reachable)</li><li>CFD (Communication Forwarding Default)</li><li>HOLD (Communication Hold)</li><li>BAOC (Barring of all outgoing calls)</li><li>BOIC (Barring of all outgoing international calls)</li><li>BOICEXHC (Barring of all outgoing international calls except those directed to the home plmn country)</li><li>BAIC (Barring of all incoming calls)</li><li>BICROAM (Barring of all incoming calls when roaming outside the home plmn country)</li><li>ODBBAOC (Operator Determined Barring of all outgoing calls)</li><li>ODBBOIC (Operator Determined Barring of all outgoing international calls)</li><li>ODBBOICEXHC (Operator Determined Barring of all outgoing international calls except those directed to the home plmn country)</li><li>ODBBAIC (Operator Determined Barring of all incoming calls)</li><li>CW (Communication Waiting)</li><li>CCBS (Completion of Communications to Busy Subscriber)</li><li>RBT (Ring Back Tone)</li><li>CONF (Conference Service)</li><li>ALLSS – All Supplementary Services listed above.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The rule for this suppression of services can be defined in one or more translation profiles. When a service suppression criteria defined in a particular translation profile matches, that service will remain suppressed for the remaining of that call leg. This suppression is specific for a particular call leg and will not be carried forward to any connected call leg.</p><p>When a particular supplementary service is identified to be suppressed, the CTAS will process the INVITE request without invoking that particular service i.e. similar to when that particular service is not implemented at the CTAS.</p><h3><a id="7.3.3 SKIP Service"></a><a id="_bookmark128"></a><a id="_bookmark128"></a>SKIP Service</h3><p>In addition to suppression of Supplementary Services, it is possible to skip other integrated CTAS services. This is done by defining SKIP flags for these services. These SKIP flags are set by various translation profiles invoked at different Point In Calls.</p><p>Below is the list of SKIP Flags supported at the CTAS:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>SKIP Flag</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Description</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_ENUM</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to SKIP invocation of ENUM Query.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_UDR</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to SKIP retrieving Service Data from the UDR.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_RF</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to SKIP Rf based Offline Charging</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_CDR</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to SKIP CDR based Offline Charging.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_RO</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to SKIP Ro based Online Charging</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>SKIP Flag</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Description</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_TADS</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to SKIP TADS query at the SCC</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_INAP</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to suppress invocation of INAP trigger.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_CAP</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to suppress invocation of CAP trigger.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_ANNC</p></td><td><p>This flag is used to suppress applying announcement.</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.3.4 Interaction Logic"></a><a id="_bookmark129"></a><a id="_bookmark129"></a>Interaction Logic</h3><p>The Service Broker manages the execution of the integrated application based on service interaction logic. The interaction logic is based on set of rules configured using SIP METHOD, SIP HEADER NAME, SIP HEADER VALUE, Source Application and order in which the configured rules must be executed. The matching entry will define the Next Application to be invoked, which determines the route to be taken for a particular request. The SB manages the execution of the services or applications based on these rules.</p><p>SB function is controlled by the configuration defined in the <strong>APPSELECTOR </strong>table with following columns, combination of all the 4 columns being unique:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><strong>PRIORITY </strong>– Identifies the order in which the entry matching must be performed, with 0 being the highest priority.</li><li><strong>METHOD </strong>– Identifies the SIP method of the Initial Request.</li><li><strong>HDRNAME </strong>– Identifies the SIP header of the Initial Request to be used for evaluating the matching condition.</li><li><strong>HDRVALUE </strong>– Identifies the SIP header value to be used for evaluating the matching condition. The matching of the header value will be based REGEXP.</li><li><strong>CURRENTAPP </strong>– Identifies the source node which is initiating this request. When the source is the SIP ISC Interface, the CURRENTAPP will be set to “SIP”.</li><li><strong>NEXTAPP </strong>– Identifies the destination node where the request needs to be forwarded.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The following use case demonstrates how iFCs in the S-CSCF and interaction logic in the Service Broker work together to manage IMS Service interactions and integrations.</p><p>IN SCP</p><p><strong>IDP [TDP2</strong></p><p><strong>and/or TDP3]</strong></p><p>CLDPN = UE-2</p><p><strong>CTAS</strong></p><p><strong>(orig)</strong></p><p>IM-SSF</p><p><strong>CUE/</strong></p><p><strong>CON</strong></p><p>SB</p><p><strong>Non-MMTEL AS</strong></p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>(UE-2)</p><p>Orig</p><p>iFC</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>(UE-2)</p><p>S-CSCF</p><p>IN SCP</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>UE-1</p><p>sip:+CC NDC SN @&lt;domain&gt;</p><p>;user=phone or</p><p>tel:+CC NDC SN</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>(UE-2)</p><p>BGCF</p><p><strong>IDP [TDP12]</strong></p><p>CLDPN = UE-2</p><p><strong>CUE/</strong></p><p><strong>CON</strong></p><p>IM-SSF</p><p><strong>CTAS</strong></p><p><strong>(term)</strong></p><p>IMS HSS FE\tSB</p><p>UDR</p><p><strong>Non-MMTEL AS</strong></p><p><strong>Cx LIR</strong></p><p>Public-Identity = UE-2</p><p><strong>Cx LIA</strong></p><p>S-CSCF Address</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>(UE-2)</p><p>Term iFC</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>(UE-2)</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>I-CSCF</p><p>(UE-2)</p><p><strong>INVITE</strong></p><p>Registered contact address</p><p>S-CSCF</p><p>UE-2</p><p>P-Called-Party-ID =</p><p>sip: + CC NDC SN @ own.com</p><p>The use case is to invoke integrated IM-SSF for non-MMTEL voice origination session. The iFC of the user invoking the non-MMTEL voice origination session will have the following iFC configured:</p><p>&lt;InitialFilterCriteria&gt;</p><p>&lt;Priority&gt;11&lt;/Priority&gt;</p><p>&lt;TriggerPoint&gt;</p><p>&lt;ConditionTypeCNF&gt;1&lt;/ConditionTypeCNF&gt;</p><p>&lt;SPT&gt;</p><p>&lt;/SPT&gt;</p><p>&lt;SPT&gt;</p><p>&lt;/SPT&gt;</p><p>&lt;SPT&gt;</p><p>&lt;/SPT&gt;</p><p>&lt;Group&gt;0&lt;/Group&gt;</p><p>&lt;Method&gt;INVITE&lt;/Method&gt;</p><p>&lt;Group&gt;2&lt;/Group&gt;</p><p>&lt;SessionCase&gt;0&lt;/SessionCase&gt;</p><p>&lt;Group&gt;2&lt;/Group&gt;</p><p>&lt;SessionCase&gt;3&lt;/SessionCase&gt;</p><p>&lt;/TriggerPoint&gt;</p><p>&lt;ApplicationServer&gt;</p><p>&lt;ServerName&gt;sip:URI_OF_CTAS;lr;orig;imssf;transport=tcp&lt;/ServerName&gt;</p><p>&lt;DefaultHandling&gt;0&lt;/DefaultHandling&gt;</p><p>&lt;/ApplicationServer&gt;</p><p>&lt;ProfilePartIndicator&gt;0&lt;/ProfilePartIndicator&gt;</p><p>&lt;/InitialFilterCriteria&gt;</p><p>The SB will have the following rule configured:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>PRIORITY</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>METHOD</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>HDRNAME</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>HDRVALUE</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>CURRENTAPP</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>NEXTAPP</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>0</p></td><td><p>INVITE</p></td><td><p>ROUTE</p></td><td><p>imssf</p></td><td><p>SIP</p></td><td><p>MMTEL</p></td></tr></table><p>When this Initial INVITE request is routed to the CTAS with the Route header containing the CTAS FQDN and “imssf” service token included, the above rule will match and the request will be routed to the MMTEL Application.</p><p>At the MMTEL Application, the Service Screening (SVCSCR) Profile will be configured with following rule:</p><table><tr><td rowspan="3"><p><strong>RuleSet Name</strong></p></td><td rowspan="3"><p><strong>Priority</strong></p></td><td rowspan="3"><p><strong>Operand</strong></p></td><td colspan="2"><p><strong>Rule</strong></p></td><td colspan="3"><p><strong>Action</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p><strong>Group</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>(SPT Element = Value)</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Action Element</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Sub-Action</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Value</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="5"><p>0</p></td><td rowspan="5"><p>SVCTOKEN = imssf</p></td><td rowspan="2"><p>APPTYPE</p></td><td rowspan="2"></td><td rowspan="2"><p>IMSSF</p></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4"><p>IMSSF</p></td><td rowspan="4"><p>0</p></td><td rowspan="4"><p>AND</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SUPSVCLIST</p></td><td></td><td><p>ALLSS</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>SKIP_UDR</p></td><td></td><td><p>TRUE</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CAUSE</p></td><td></td><td><p>EXIT</p></td></tr></table><p>As per this rule the Initial INVITE request will be processed similar to an MMTEL session, but after suppression of all Supplementary Services and user profile retrieval.</p><p>After completion of call processing logic at the MMTEL Application, the request will be routed back to the SB to determine the next application, if any.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>PRIORITY</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>METHOD</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>HDRNAME</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>HDRVALUE</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>CURRENTAPP</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>NEXTAPP</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>1</p></td><td><p>INVITE</p></td><td><p>ROUTE</p></td><td><p>imssf</p></td><td><p>MMTEL</p></td><td><p>SIP</p></td></tr></table><p>Since the current application is MMTEL, the above defined rule will match, where the next application is defined to be the SIP ISC Interface, which will cause the request to be routed back to the S-CSCF over the ISC interface.</p><h2><a id="7.4 Supplementary Services"></a><a id="_bookmark130"></a><a id="_bookmark130"></a>Supplementary Services</h2><h3><a id="7.4.1 Originating Identity Presentation "></a><a id="_bookmark131"></a><a id="_bookmark131"></a>Originating Identity Presentation (OIP) &amp; Restriction (OIR)</h3><p>The Originating Identification Presentation (OIP) service provides the terminating user with the possibility of receiving identity information in order to identify the originating user.</p><p>The supported OIP service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The OIP subscription option supported is:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Subscription option values</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>originating-identity-presentation</p></td><td><p>Active/Inactive</p></td></tr></table><p>There is also a network provided override category which allows the operator to override the OIP setting of the subscriber.</p><p>The Originating Identification Restriction (OIR) service enables the originating user to prevent presentation of its identity information to the terminating user.</p><p>The supported OIR service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The OIR subscription options supported are:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Subscription option values</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"><p>Mode</p></td><td><p>- temporary mode (specified by the user per the initial outgoing request)</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>- permanent</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Temporary mode default</p></td><td><ul><li>presentation restricted</li><li>presentation not restricted</li></ul></td></tr></table><p>The CTAS will support the following network wide configuration:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Network option</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>No screening</p><p>Note: Even though this is a network wide option, it may be overridden by the user profile settings.</p></td><td><p>Active/Inactive</p></td></tr></table><p>The CTAS will support following configuration table for setting Privacy header when OIR service is subscribed:</p><h4>Privacy Header for OIR</h4><table><tr><td><p><strong>Field Name</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Field Description</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Allowed Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Subscription Mode</p></td><td><p>Identifies the subscription mode</p><p>– permanent or temporary.</p></td><td><ul><li>PERMANENT</li><li>TEMP_RESTRICTED</li><li>TEMP_NOTRESTRICTED</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><p>Restriction</p></td><td><p>Identifies whether to restrict the asserted identity or to restrict all</p><p>the\tprivate\tinformation appearing in headers</p></td><td><ul><li>ASSERTED_ID</li><li>ALL_PRIVATE_INFO</li><li>NA (Not applicable)</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><p>Privacy Header</p></td><td><p>dentifies operation defined priv- value for Privacy Header. This field can have multiple comma separated values.</p></td><td><ul><li>user</li><li>id</li><li>header</li></ul></td></tr></table><p>CTAS supports OIP and OIR service as defined in 3GPP TS 24.607 <a href="#_bookmark7">[16] </a>which includes:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>If user has not subscribed to OIP, terminating AS removes P-Asserted-Identity and Privacy header fields, replaces From header with “anonymous” identity.</li><li>OIP override option is supported for terminating user. CTAS removes Privacy header set to “id” when OIP override option is enabled for the terminating user.</li><li>Originating identity screening. If OIR is not active for the originating user, the CTAS performs screening of identity included in the From header by matching it with the set of registered public identities. If no match is found, CTAS replaces the value of the From header with network provided identity from the P-Asserted-Identity header.</li><li>Originating display name screening. If OIR is not active for the originating user, the CTAS performs screening of display name included in the From header by matching it with display name provisioned for the used identity. If a match is not found or no display name is provisioned for the user identity, CTAS removes display name from the request.</li><li>White list for no screening option on a per user basis. CTAS does not screen the originating user's identity information in the From header intended to be transparently transported by the network, based on subscription option. There is currently no subscriber specific “no screening” subscription option defined in the UDR, hence this option by default becomes network wide and applicable for all subscribers.</li><li>Prevention of premium number ping. CTAS changes the originating user’s identity information in the From header of requests originating from Premium Rate numbers to “Anonymous” identity. This can be controlled in such a way that the modifying originating user’s identity can be done only for a specific premium number or a group of premium numbers.</li><li>OIR service is supported in permanent and temporary subscription modes. In case of temporary mode both default options – presentation restricted and presentation not restricted are supported.</li><li>OIR service supports restriction of asserted identity and restriction of all private information appearing in the headers as subscribed by the user. This is applied by default whenever the OIR service is set to permanent mode or temporary mode-presentation restricted.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p></p><p>CTAS manipulates Privacy header as defined in the table below –</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Subscription</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Privacy Header</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Originating CTAS</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Terminating CTAS</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Not subscribed</p></td><td><p>*</p></td><td><p>Removes Privacy Header</p></td><td><p>-</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Permanent</p></td><td><p>*</p></td><td><ul><li>Adds Privacy header with priv- values as configured in “Privacy Header for OIR” for subscription option as PREMANENT and application restriction</li><li>A priv-value of “none” is removed, if present.</li><li>Adds priv-value “header” if presentation restriction option is “all-private-information” (if not already included)</li><li>Adds priv-value “id” if presentation restriction option is “restrict the asserted identity” (if not already included)Applies full privacy service.</li><li>If anonymization of From header is required then it is done only if “anonymizeFromHeader” is TRUE. If anonymization is needed as per privacy rules but “anonymizeFromHeader” flag is FALSE then CTAS adds priv-value “user” in Privacy header (if not included) in outgoing INVITE.</li></ul></td><td><p>If priv-value of “header” is included in the Privacy header, Terminating CTAS adds priv-value of “id” if not already present.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Temporary, Presentation restricted</p></td><td><p>none</p></td><td><p>Privacy is not applied</p></td><td></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p>Temporary, Presentation restricted</p></td><td><ul><li>Privacy: Any combination of {id, header, user}</li><li>or no Privacy header present</li></ul></td><td><ul><li>Adds Privacy header with priv-values as configured in “Privacy Header for OIR” for subscription option as TEMP_RESTRICTED and application restriction</li><li>Adds priv-value “header” if presentation restriction option is “all-private- information” (if not already included)</li><li>Adds priv-value “id” if presentation restriction option is “restrict the asserted identity” (if not already included)Applies full privacy service.</li><li>If anonymization of From header is required then it is done only if “anonymizeFromHeader” is TRUE. If anonymization is needed as per privacy rules but “anonymizeFromHeader” flag is FALSE then CTAS adds priv-value “user” in Privacy header (if not included) in outgoing INVITE.</li></ul></td><td><p>If priv-value of “header” is included in the Privacy header, Terminating CTAS adds priv-value of “id” if not already present.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Temporary, Presentation not restricted</p></td><td><p>none</p><p>or no Privacy header present</p></td><td><p>Privacy is not applied</p></td><td></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p>Temporary, Presentation not restricted</p></td><td><p>Privacy: Any combination of {id, header, user}</p></td><td><ul><li>Adds Privacy header with priv- values as configured in “Privacy Header for OIR” for subscription option as TEMP_NOTRESTRICTED and application restriction</li><li>Adds priv-value “header” if presentation restriction option is “all-private-information” (if not already included)</li><li>Adds priv-value “id” if presentation restriction option is “restrict the asserted identity” (if not already included)</li><li>If priv-value of “header” is included in the Privacy header, Originating CTAS adds priv- value of “id” if not already present.</li><li>Applies requested privacy service.</li><li>If anonymization of From header is required then it is done only if “anonymizeFromHeader” is TRUE. If anonymization is needed as per privacy rules but “anonymizeFromHeader” flag is FALSE then CTAS adds priv-value “user” in Privacy header (if not included) in outgoing INVITE.</li></ul></td><td><p>If priv-value of “header” is included in the Privacy header, Terminating CTAS adds priv-value of “id” if not already present.</p></td></tr></table><p>CTAS applies privacy services as defined in the table 5)</p></td><td><p>-</p></td><td><p>anonymize (Note 5)</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>In-Reply-To</p></td><td><p>R</p></td><td><p>delete</p></td><td><p>-</p></td><td><p>-</p></td><td><p>-</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Organization</p></td><td><p>Rr</p></td><td><p>delete</p></td><td><p>don't The only scenario in which it is removed in at the terminating CTAS in compliance with 24.607 section 4.5.2.9 if OIP service of the terminating user is not activated and at originating CTAS in compliance with 24.608 section 4.5.2.4 if an originating user does not subscribe to the TIP service.</p><p>Note 2: If "user" privacy is requested in an incoming REFER request, CTAS will anonymize the Referred-By header in outgoing re-INVITE requests. CTAS deletes the headers to achieve this.</p><p>Note 6: According to 3GPP TS 24.607 the AS serving the terminating UE shall remove or anonymize the contents of the From header if incoming the request includes the Privacy header field set to "user". In this release the TAS serving the originating UE provides configuration option for “From” header anonymization or to skip it and add “user” privacy.</p><p>The service interactions of the OIP/OIR user.</p></td><td><p>NA</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No of the originating call on the CC call.</p><p>CTAS enforces the privacy settings of the originating call for SUBSCRIBE and NOTIFY requests when CC is invoked.</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.4.2 Terminating Identity Presentation "></a><a id="_bookmark132"></a><a id="_bookmark132"></a>Terminating Identity Presentation (TIP) &amp; Restriction (TIR)</h3><p>The Terminating Identification Presentation (TIP) service provides the originating party with the possibility of receiving identity information in order to identify the terminating party.</p><p>The supported TIP service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The TIP subscription option supported is:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Subscription option values</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>terminating-identity-presentation</p></td><td><p>Active/Inactive</p></td></tr></table><p>There is also a network provided override category which allows the operator to override the TIP setting of the subscriber.</p><p>The Terminating Identification Restriction (TIR) is a service offered to the connected party which enables the connected party to prevent presentation of the terminating identity information to originating party.</p><p>The supported TIR service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is applicable The subscription option supported is:</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><table><tr><td><p><strong>Subscription option values</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Mode</p></td><td><p>- temporary mode (specified by the user per request)</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Temporary mode default</p></td><td><ul><li>presentation restricted</li><li>presentation not restricted</li></ul></td></tr></table><p>The CTAS will support the following network wide configuration for Line-Id:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Network option</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Values</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>No screening</p><p>Note: Even though this is a network wide option, it may be overridden by the user profile settings.</p></td><td><p>Active/Inactive</p></td></tr></table><p>CTAS supports TIP and TIR service as defined in 3GPP TS 24.608 <a href="#_bookmark8">[17] </a>which includes:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>TIR service is supported in permanent and temporary subscription modes. In case of temporary mode both default options – presentation restricted and presentation not restricted are supported.</li><li>TIR override option is supported for originating user. CTAS removes the Privacy header set to “id” when TIR override option is enabled for the originating user</li><li>Called user identity screening. If TIR is not active for the terminating user, the CTAS performs screening of identity included in the From header of UPDATE request by matching it with the set of registered public identities. If no match is found, CTAS replaces the value of the From header in UPDATE request with network provided identity from the P-Asserted-Identity header.</li><li>Called user display name screening. If TIR is not active for the terminating user, the CTAS performs screening of display name included in From header of UPDATE request by matching it with display name provisioned for the used identity. If a match is not found or no display name is provisioned for the user identity, CTAS removes display name from the UPDATE request.</li><li>White list for no screening option on a per user basis. CTAS does not screen the originating user's identity information in the From header of UPDATE request intended to be transparently transported by the network, based on subscription option. There is currently no subscriber specific “no screening” subscription option defined in the UDR, hence this option by default becomes network wide and applicable for all subscribers.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The service interactions of the TIP/TIR services with other supplementary services are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>TIP Interaction</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>TIR Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIP</p></td><td><p>NA</p></td><td><p>TIR service takes precedence over the TIP service, unless Restriction override is active for the terminating user.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIR</p></td><td><p>TIR service takes precedence over the TIP service, unless Restriction override is active for the terminating user.</p></td><td></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>TIP Interaction</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>TIR Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV</p></td><td><p>The diverted-to user’s identity information is presented to originating user only if TIP subscription is active. In addition, diverted-to user’s identity information is controlled based on terminating user’s subscription.</p><p>If originating user has Restriction override active, diverted-to user’s identity information is presented when the communication is answered.</p></td><td><p>The diverted-to user's identity information is not presented to the originating user, if TIR is active in permanent mode.</p><p>The diverted-to user's identity information is presented to the originating user during a positive response to the call, if TIR is active in temporary mode.</p><p>If originating user has Restriction override active, diverted-to user’s identity information is presented when the communication is answered.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CB/ODB</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CW</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>HOLD</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CONF</p></td><td><p>Participants in a conference do not receive the TIP service information of participants being added to the conference.</p></td><td><p>If a participant has joined the conference as a terminating party and has TIR active, then the identity information of that participant is not included in the conference event notifications to other participants.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CCBS</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>CTAS enforces the privacy settings of the CC recall answer on the CC call and if necessary on the subsequent communication, if the CC recall is invoked via 3pcc procedures.</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.4.3 Communication Diversion (CDIV)"></a><a id="_bookmark133"></a><a id="_bookmark133"></a>Communication Diversion (CDIV)</h3><p>The Communications Diversion (CDIV) service enables diverting user, to divert the communications addressed to diverting user to another destination.</p><p>CTAS supports CDIV as defined in TS 24.604 <a href="#_bookmark9">[18] </a>which includes:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Communication Forwarding Unconditional (CFU)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Busy user (CFB)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on no Reply (CFNR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Subscriber Not Reachable (CFNRc)</li><li>Communication Deflection (CD)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Not Logged-in (CFNL)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>In addition, the CTAS supports following additional functionality related to CDIV:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Call Forwarding Default - CDIV by default means that the forwarding’s CFB, CFNR and CFNRc are always active. If the respective forwarding was not activated by the user by registering a forwarded-to number, a default forwarded-to number is automatically registered instead.</li><li>Configurable SIP and Q.850 codes for not-reachable and busy conditions</li><li>CS breakout (if user available in CS domain) before invoking CFNL</li><li>CS retry before invoking CFNRc for configurable SIP response codes</li><li>Notification to the originating user that his communication has been diverted</li><li>Checking of diversion limits with possible exception when the forwarding number is a Voicemail number</li><li>Checking of parallel diversion limits</li><li>CF Suppression based on the type of CDIV i.e. User Controlled Call Forwarding (UCCF) variant or Operator Controlled Call Forwarding (OCCF) variant and roaming status.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The figure below shows a high level flow for CDIV, for more details refer to the CDIV Use Case Description document <a href="#_bookmark24">[35].</a></p><p>SCC</p><p>IN SCP</p><p>CDIV condition detected by T-CTAS:</p><p>- CFU configured</p><p>If CFU Notify Calling Party subscription is enabled originating user id="_bookmark134"></a><a id="_bookmark134"></a>Conference (CONF)</h3><p>The CONFerence (CONF) service enables a user to participate in and control a simultaneous communication involving a number of users.</p><p>CTAS supports the CONF service as defined in 24.605 <a href="#_bookmark10">[19] </a>which include:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Three-way session creation using conference factory URI</li><li>User inviting another user to a conference</li><li>3rd party call control (3pcc) procedures for special handling of REFER request as defined in 24.628 <a href="#_bookmark11">[21] </a>to avoid sending REFER to remote party and instead use re-INVITE to add user to conference.</li><li>Conference event package with support for the following elements and attributes:<ul><li>Conference-info: entity</li><li>Maximum-user-count</li><li>Users</li><li>User: entity</li><li>Endpoint: entity</li><li>Status (supported values: connected, disconnected, on-hold)</li></ul></li><li>Leaving a conference<ul><li>Controller leaving a conference</li><li>Controller removing a conference participant from a conference using a REFER request sent within the existing dialog for a conference session containing.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Conference URI in the RURI and</p><p>A Refer-To header including a valid IMPU for the user to be removed and the “method” parameter set to “BYE”</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Configurable conference termination policy, with option to terminate conference when either the conference controller leaves or when the last non-controlling participant leaves.</li><li>Media type supported is audio</li><li>Maximum participants supported are configurable with default being 6.</li><li>Blocking of calls made to premium numbers.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the Conference Use Case Description document <a href="#_bookmark19">[30] </a>for details.</p><h3><a id="7.4.5 Communication Hold (HOLD)"></a><a id="_bookmark135"></a><a id="_bookmark135"></a>Communication Hold (HOLD)</h3><p>The Communication Hold supplementary service enables a user to suspend the reception of media stream(s) of an established IP multimedia session, and resume the media stream(s) at a later time.</p><p>The supported HOLD service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is not applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>CTAS supports HOLD service as defined in 24.610 <a href="#_bookmark12">[22] </a>which include:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Service configuration i.e. the user is allowed to place the call on hold only if hold service is enabled in the user profile.</li><li>Playing tones/announcements towards held user, with the following exception:<ul><li>If a participant of a conference invokes a HOLD service, the CTAS will not provide announcement/tone to the held user.</li></ul></li><li>Limit parallel calls on hold, with configurable allowed limit, by limiting the number of maximum active communications for the served user.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The service interactions of the CH service with other supplementary services are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>HOLD Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CB/ODB</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CW</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>HOLD</p></td><td><p>NA</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CONF</p></td><td><p>If a participant of a conference invokes the HOLD service, CTAS will not initiate announcement/tone procedures towards the held user.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CCBS</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.4.6 Communication Barring (CB)"></a><a id="_bookmark136"></a><a id="_bookmark136"></a>Communication Barring (CB)</h3><p>The Communication Barring (CB) service offers the following services:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>The Incoming Communication Barring (ICB) is a service that rejects incoming communications that fulfill certain provisioned or configured conditions on behalf of the terminating user.</li><li>The Outgoing Communication Barring (OCB) is a service that rejects outgoing communications that fulfill certain provisioned or configured conditions on behalf of the originating user.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The supported ICB service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The ICB types supported are described in the table below:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Barring Class</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Treatment</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>BAIC</p></td><td><p>Barring All Incoming Calls</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>BICRoam</p></td><td><p>Barring of all Incoming Calls when roaming outside the home plmn country.</p></td></tr></table><p>The supported OCB service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The OCB Types supported are described in the table below:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Barring Class</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Treatment</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>BAOC</p></td><td><p>Barring of All Outgoing Calls</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>BOIC</p></td><td><p>Barring of all outgoing international calls</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>BOICExHC</p></td><td><p>Barring of all outgoing international calls except those directed to the home PLMN country</p></td></tr></table><p>CTAS supports CB as defined in 24.611 <a href="#_bookmark13">[23] </a>which include,</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Service Provisioning - The CB service is provided only if enabled in the user profile. By default, when CB service is disabled in the user profile, CB service is not provided to the user.</li><li>Barring of all outgoing calls (BAOC)</li><li>Barring of all outgoing international calls (BOIC). Translation rules will need to be configured to analyze the dialed digit pattern to identity international dialing. The CALLTYPE set by the translation will be used to apply barring of all outgoing international calls.</li><li>Barring of all outgoing international calls except those directed to the home PLMN country (BOICexHC). If the user is roaming, outgoing international calls except those directed to home PLMN country are rejected. Translation rules will need to be configured to identify roaming status of the originator. The VLR address of the served originating user is used to identify international calls i.e. when the VLR address does not begin with the CC matching that of the called party digits, the call is considered as international call. Called party number starting with CC of the home country is considered call to home country.</li><li>Barring of all incoming calls (BAIC).</li><li>Barring of all incoming calls when roaming outside the home PLMN country (BICRoam). If the user is roaming, as identified by his VLR address, all incoming calls are rejected.</li><li>CTAS provides the capability to play an announcement for the barred call.</li><li>ICB service takes precedence over Communication Diversion for the served user.</li><li>OCB service takes precedence over outgoing communication towards the targeted-to user.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The service interactions of the CB service with other supplementary services are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>ICB Interaction</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>OCB Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>ICB Interaction</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>OCB Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV</p></td><td><p>ICB service takes precedence over the Communication Diversion service for the served user.</p><p>ICB service is also applied for the diverted-to user.</p><p>ODB services takes precedence over CDIV service.</p></td><td><p>The OCB service takes precedence on the outgoing communication towards the targeted-to user.</p><p>OCB service is also applied for the diverting user.</p><p>ODB takes precedence over CDIV service.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CB/ODB</p></td><td><p>ICB service takes precedence over ODB services.</p></td><td><p>OCB service takes precedence over ODB services.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CW</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>HOLD</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CONF</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>OCB service takes precedence over Conference. If OCB service is active, the conference creation request is rejected. If the OCB service is activated after conference has been established, any outgoing calls in progress within that conference will not be barred.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CCBS</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.4.7 Operator Determined Barring (ODB)"></a><a id="_bookmark137"></a><a id="_bookmark137"></a>Operator Determined Barring (ODB)</h3><p>The Operator Determined Barring is similar to CB service except that the ODB service is controlled by the operator. The Subscriber profile will contain Operator Determined Barring (ODB) options which are configured against the subscriber at the UDR.</p><p>The ODB types supported are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Barring Class</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Treatment</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><p><strong>ODB-General Data</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>odbBAOC</p></td><td><p>Takes the following values:</p><ul><li>0 None</li><li>1 Outgoing Calls</li><li>2 Outgoing International calls</li><li>3 Outgoing International Calls exHC</li><li>4 Outgoing Calls while Roaming</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><p>odbBAIC</p></td><td><p>Takes the following values:</p><ul><li>0 None</li><li>1 Incoming calls</li><li>2 Incoming calls while roaming</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Barring Class</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Treatment</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>odbBAPREM</p></td><td><p>Takes the following values:</p><ul><li>0 None</li><li>1 Outgoing Premium Rate calls (Information)</li><li>2 Outgoing Premium Rate calls (Entertainment)</li><li>3 All Outgoing Premium Rate calls</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><p><strong>ODB-PLMN Data</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Operator Determined Barring Type 1</p></td><td><p>Rules based on the leading digits with the length up to the complete number.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Operator Determined Barring Type 2</p></td><td><p>Rules based on the leading digits with the length up to the complete number.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Operator Determined Barring Type 3</p></td><td><p>Rules based on the leading digits with the length up to the complete number.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Operator Determined Barring Type 4</p></td><td><p>Rules based on the leading digits with the length up to the complete number.</p></td></tr></table><p>CTAS supports ODB as defined in 22.041 <a href="#_bookmark14">[24] </a>which include,</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Barring of all outgoing calls (odbBaoc)</li><li>Barring of all outgoing international calls (odbBaoc). Translation rules will need to be configured to analyze the dialed digit pattern to identity international dialing. The CALLTYPE set by the translation will be used to apply barring of all outgoing international calls.</li><li>Barring of all outgoing international calls except those directed to the home PLMN country (odbBaoc). If the user is roaming, outgoing international calls except those directed to home PLMN country are rejected. Translation rules will need to configured to identify roaming status of the originator. The VLR address of the served originating user is used to identify international calls i.e. when the VLR address does not begin with the CC matching that of the called party digits, the call is considered as international call. Called party number starting with CC of the home country is considered call to home country.</li><li>Barring of outgoing calls while roaming. Translation rules will be configured to identify the roaming status of originating user.</li><li>Barring of all incoming calls (odbBaic).</li><li>Barring of all incoming calls when roaming outside the home PLMN country (odbBaic). If the user is roaming, as identified by his VLR address, all incoming calls are rejected.</li><li>Barring of outgoing Premium Rate Calls (Information) (odbBaprem). Translation rules needs to be configured to identify digit pattern for premium rate calls.</li><li>Barring of outgoing Premium Rate Calls (Entertainment) (odbBaprem). Translation rules needs to be configured to identify digit pattern for premium rate calls.</li><li>Operator Specific Barring Type 1 – Type 4 (odbHplmn). Based on the leading digits configured in translation rules, calls are rejected.</li><li>CTAS provides the capability to play an announcement for the barred call.</li><li>Operator Determined Barring of Subscriber Controlled Input (applicable for SIP based user configuration only). CTAS rejects Subscriber Controlled Input if the subscription option is not configured in the Subscriber profile.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>CTAS supports following additional functionality related to ODB:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>ODB service provisioning is specific to device hence the ODB service is applied based on the device which is originating the request or the device to which the request is terminated to.</li><li>Activation of ODB will cause termination of calls of a user that has been established prior to the application of the ODB service and which are still ongoing.</li><li>ODB service takes precedence over CDIV for the served user.</li><li>ICB/OCB services take precedence over ODB for the served user.</li><li>ODB service takes precedence over outgoing communication towards the targeted-to user.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The service interactions of the ODB service with other supplementary services are described in the table in section <a href="#_bookmark136">7.4.6.</a></p><h3><a id="7.4.8 Communication Waiting (CW)"></a><a id="_bookmark138"></a><a id="_bookmark138"></a>Communication Waiting (CW)</h3><p>The Communication Waiting (CW) service enables a UE to be informed that no resources are available for an incoming communication. The user then has the choice of accepting, rejecting or ignoring the incoming communication (as per basic communication procedures).</p><p>The supported CW service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning or by user</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal or by user</li><li>Registration is Not Applicable</li><li>Erasure is Not Applicable</li><li>Interrogation is Applicable The subscription option supported is:</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><table><tr><td><p><strong>Subscription options</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Value</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p><em>Served user </em>subscribes to “calling user receives notification that his call is waiting"</p></td><td><p>No</p><p>Yes (default)</p></td></tr></table><p>CTAS supports terminal-based CW service as defined in 24.615 <a href="#_bookmark15">[25] </a>which include:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>When the served terminating user has one or more active calls in progress, if the served user has CW service active, the CTAS will not apply NDUB and will always route the call termination request to the UE.</li><li>When the served terminating user is in the middle of call establishment i.e. call has not transitioned to active/connected state, the CTAS will apply NDUB and invoke CFB if active.</li><li>CTAS will provide CW indication in the form of announcement/tone,<ul><li>when 180 Ringing is received from the remote end with Alert-Info header field set to "&lt;urn:alert:service:call-waiting&gt;" or</li><li>when 180 (Ringing) is received from the served terminating user who has one or more active call dialog(s)</li></ul></li><li>CTAS will support the configurable timer “Call Waiting Timer” to supervise the time CW is applied.</li><li>When user accepts a waiting call, if the number of active communications exceeds the limit, CTAS will release the previous active call.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>CTAS supports network-based CW service as defined in 24.615 <a href="#_bookmark15">[25] </a>which include:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>The maximum number of total communications permitted has been reached. The total communications permitted is controlled by a configurable parameter.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>CTAS supports a configurable option to disable NDUB, thus ensuring all calls are presented to the served terminating user irrespective of the NDUB condition match.</p><p>The service interactions of the CW service with other supplementary services are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>HOLD Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIR</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV</p></td><td><p>CFU takes precedence over CW service.</p><p>CFU activation while a communication is waiting is not applied for the waiting communication.</p><p>If CW invoked results in UDUB, CTAS invokes CFB if subscribed.</p><p>CFNR is invoked if noReplyTimer expires after invoking CW.</p><p>CFNRc is invoked if notReachableTimer expires after invoking CW.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CB/ODB</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CW</p></td><td><p>NA</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>HOLD</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CONF</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CCBS</p></td><td><p>CTAS does not invoke the CW service on a CC recall.</p><p>If the communication waiting indication cannot be given at the destination B, user A will receive busy indication and can invoke the CCBS service to destination B.</p></td></tr></table><h3><a id="7.4.9 Completion of Communications to Bu"></a><a id="_bookmark139"></a><a id="_bookmark139"></a>Completion of Communications to Busy Subscriber (CCBS)</h3><p>The CCBS services enables a user, encountering a destination that is busy, to have the communication completed at a later point in time without the user having to manually initiate a new communication attempt when the destination B becomes not busy.</p><p>The supported CCBS service procedures are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Activated at provisioning</li><li>Deactivated at withdrawal</li><li>Registration is not applicable</li><li>Erasure is not applicable</li><li>Interrogation is not applicable</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>CTAS supports CCBS service as defined in 24.642 <a href="#_bookmark16">[26], </a>which include:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>CCBS is a subscription based service and hence will be invoked only if the corresponding flag is enabled in the user profile.</li><li>CCBS activation is supported in both user confirmation mode and automatic activation mode.</li><li>Communication completion procedures using both REFER method and 3rd party call control procedures.</li><li>Configurable option to not invoke CCBS service retention procedure, if CCBS is already active on an identical communication.</li><li>Identical communication is identified as calls with the same<ul><li>From header field</li><li>To header field</li><li>Request-URI field</li><li>SDP offer</li><li>Privacy header field</li><li>P-Asserted-Identity header field</li></ul></li><li>Configurable option for the operator to control if user A is informed about CC possibility at user B.</li><li>Configurable option to control network provider option “CC request retention”, separately for each network.</li><li>Configurable queue length for the operator to control the number of outstanding communication completion requests per user.</li><li>Configurable user level parameter for the operator to control the number of outstanding communication completion requests against one destination</li><li>Configurable network level parameter for the operator to control the number of outstanding communication completion requests against one destination, when per user queue configuration is deactivated.</li><li>Communication completion requests are processed in a first-in first-out fashion.</li><li>Communication completion support for a UE that has Multi-SIM Account.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The service interactions of the CCBS service with other supplementary services are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>CCBS Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIR</p></td><td><p>CTAS enforces the privacy settings of the originating call on the CC call.</p><p>CTAS enforces the privacy settings of the originating call for SUBSCRIBE and NOTIFY requests when CC is invoked.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIP</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>TIR</p></td><td><p>CTAS enforces the privacy settings of the CC recall answer on the CC call and if necessary on the subsequent communication, if the CC recall is invoked via 3pcc procedures.</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>CCBS Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV-CFU</p></td><td><p><strong>For CFU activated by B before A requests CC on B:</strong></p><ol><li>If Disable CCBS If CFU parameter is False, user B has activated CFU, and the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, the originating TAS will inform user A that CC is possible at user C.</li></ol><p>Note: If user A activates CC and subsequently activates CFU, the originating TAS will give the CC recall to user A at his original location.</p><ol><li>If Disable CCBS If CFU parameter is True, user B has activated CFU, and the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, the originating TAS will not inform user A that CC is possible.</li></ol><p><strong>For CFU activated by B after A requests CC on B:</strong></p><ol><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFU Activated parameter is set to False, and if user B activates CFU after user A has activated CC on user B, then the terminating TAS will cancel the CC request and will send a notification "CC cancelled" to the user A.</li><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFU Activated parameter is set to True, the terminating TAS will suspend (stop monitoring user B to become not busy or CC busy) the CC request until user B deactivates CFU. If the service duration timer CC-T3 expires before user B deactivates CFU, the originating TAS will cancel the CC request. If the service duration timer CC-T7 expires before user B deactivates CFU, the terminating TAS will cancel the CC request.</li><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFU Activated parameter is set to True, the terminating TAS will resume (start monitoring user B to become not busy or CC busy) each suspended CC request due to user B activating CFU, when user B deactivates CFU.</li></ol></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV-CFB</p></td><td><p><strong>For CFB activated by B before A requests CC:</strong></p><ol><li>If Invoke CCBS on CLDPTY if CFB parameter is set to False, and if user B has activated CFB before user A requests CC and is busy, and if the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, the terminating TAS of B will forward the Call-Info header received from the terminating TAS of C to the originating TAS of A.</li></ol><p>Note: The originating TAS of A will inform user A that CC is possible at user C, if CCBSstatus (natCCBS) parameter in user profile is set to true and the CCBS Enable parameter is ENABLED.</p><ol><li>If Invoke CCBS on CLDPTY if CFB parameter is set to True, and if user B has activated CFB before user A requests CC and is busy, the terminating TAS of B will include a Call-Info header to indicate that CC is possible at B and sends it to the originating TAS of A.</li></ol><p>Note: The originating TAS of A will inform user A that CC is possible at user B, if CCBSstatus (natCCBS) parameter in user profile is set to true and the CCBS Enable parameter is ENABLED.</p><p><strong>For CFB activated by B after A requests CC on B:</strong></p><ol><li>If Activate CCBS If CFB Activated parameter is set to True, user B will be considered as being busy and the terminating TAS will apply the procedures of CCBS on the CC call from user A.</li><li>If Activate CCBS If CFB Activated parameter is set to False, the terminating TAS will forward the communication (i.e. the CC call from user A) as a normal communication to user C.</li></ol><p>Note: Supplementary services are not applied to this forwarded CC recall at T-TAS of user C.</p></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>CCBS Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV-CFNR</p></td><td><p><strong>For CFNR activated by B before A requests CC:</strong></p><ol><li>If Disable CCBS If CFNR parameter is False, if user B has activated CFNR and is not answering, and the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, originating TAS will inform user A that CC is possible at user C.</li><li>If Disable CCBS If CFNR parameter is True, if user B has activated CFNR and is not answering, and the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, the originating TAS will not inform user A that CC is possible.</li></ol><p><strong>For CFNR activated by B after A requests CC on B:</strong></p><ol><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFNR Activated parameter is set to False, and if user B activates CFNR after user A has activated CC on user B, for a CC call from user A which encounters a no answer condition at user B, terminating TAS will cancel the CC request and will send a notification "CC cancelled" to the user A.</li><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFNR Activated parameter is set to True, the terminating TAS will suspend (stop monitoring user B to become not busy or CC busy) the CC request until user B deactivates CFNR. If the service duration timer CC-T3 expires before user B deactivates CFU, the originating TAS will cancel the CC request. If the service duration timer CC-T7 expires before user B deactivates CFU, the terminating TAS will cancel the CC request.</li><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFNR Activated parameter is set to True, the terminating TAS will resume (start monitoring user B to become not busy or CC busy) each suspended CC request due to user B activating CFNR, when user B deactivates CFNR.</li></ol></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV-CFNRc</p></td><td><p><strong>For CFNRc activated by B before A requests CC:</strong></p><ol><li>If Disable CCBS If CFNRc parameter is False, if user B has activated CFNRc and is not answering, and the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, originating TAS will inform user A that CC is possible at user C.</li><li>If Disable CCBS If CFNRc parameter is True, if user B has activated CFNRc and is not answering, and the forwarded communication results in a call-completion condition at user C, the originating TAS will not inform user A that CC is possible.</li></ol><p><strong>For CFNRc activated by B after A requests CC on B:</strong></p><ol><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFNRc Activated parameter is set to False, and if user B activates CFNRc after user A has activated CC on user B, for a CC call from user A which encounters a not reachable condition at user B, terminating TAS will cancel the CC request and will send a notification "CC cancelled" to the user A.</li><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFNRc Activated parameter is set to True, the terminating TAS will suspend (stop monitoring user B to become not busy or CC busy) the CC request until user B deactivates CFNRc. If the service duration timer CC-T3 expires before user B deactivates CFU, the originating TAS will cancel the CC request. If the service duration timer CC-T7 expires before user B deactivates CFU, the terminating TAS will cancel the CC request.</li><li>If Suspend CCBS If CFNRc Activated parameter is set to True, the terminating TAS will resume (start monitoring user B to become not busy or CC busy) each suspended CC request due to user B activating CFNRc, when user B deactivates CFNRc.</li></ol></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>CCBS Interaction</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CDIV-CD</p></td><td><p><strong>For the originating user A:</strong></p><p>If a communication to the called user B is deflected to user C by the CD service and results in a call-completion condition at user C, TAS shall inform user A that CC is possible at user C. TAS shall not deflect a CC recall.</p><p><strong>For the called user B:</strong></p><p>TAS shall not deflect a CC call.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CB/ODB</p></td><td><p><strong>For the originating user A:</strong></p><p>If user A has OCB/ODB activated after activating CC on user B, a CC recall from user A will be rejected by originating TAS and CC request will be cancelled.</p><p><strong>For the terminating user B:</strong></p><p>If user B has ICB/ODB activated after user A has activated CC on user B, a CC recall from user A will be rejected by terminating TAS and CC request will be cancelled.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CW</p></td><td><p>CTAS does not invoke the CW service on a CC recall.</p><p>If the communication waiting indication cannot be given at the destination B, user A will receive busy indication and can invoke the CCBS service to destination B.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>HOLD</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CONF</p></td><td><p>No impact.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>CCBS</p></td><td><p>A user can be both a "user A" and a "user B" simultaneously, i.e. that user can have activated the CC service and have CC requests outstanding whilst at the same time that user can be the destination of CC requests from other users.</p><p>CTAS handles CC requests activated by user (the user's queue A) with priority over CC requests activated by other users on the user (the user’s queue B).</p></td></tr></table><p>The interworking considerations of the CCBS service with CS network are described in the table below.</p><table><tr><td colspan="5"><p><strong>Terminating user</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4"><p><strong>Originating user</strong></p></td><td></td><td><p><strong>CS subscriber</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>VoLTE subscriber IMS connected</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>VoLTE subscriber CS connected</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p><strong>CS subscriber</strong></p></td><td><p>OK</p></td><td><p>N/A - CCBS possible indication offered by terminating MMTEL but</p><p>removed by MGCF</p></td><td><p>N/A - CCBS possible indication offered by terminating MMTEL</p><p>but removed by MGCF</p></td></tr><tr><td><p><strong>VoLTE subscriber IMS connected</strong></p></td><td><p>N/A - CCBS possible indication offered by</p><p>terminating MSC but removed by MGCF</p></td><td><p>OK</p></td><td><p>Partly - CCBS possible is offered if B is busy with terminating call, therefore the MMTEL knows that user B is</p><p>busy.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p><strong>VoLTE subscriber CS connected</strong></p></td><td><p>OK</p></td><td><p>N/A - CCBS possible indication offered by terminating MMTEL but removed by MGCF</p></td><td><p>N/A - CCBS possible indication offered by terminating MMTEL but removed by MGCF</p></td></tr></table><h4><a id="7.4.9.1 CCBS Invocation"></a><a id="_bookmark140"></a><a id="_bookmark140"></a>CCBS Invocation</h4><p>The following flow shows the scenario where CTAS-B finds user B is busy and sends CCBS possible indication to CTAS-A.
