scenario where CTAS-B finds user B is busy and if following conditions are met, forwards the INVITE to cfdFTNOforCFB (using the procedures described in CDIV Use Case Description document <a href="#_bookmark24">[35]</a>), which is routed to an external call control node. The CTAS will suppress sending 181 to the caller in this case.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>CFB is not active for the terminating user, but, cfdforCFBActive set to “active” AND cfdFTNOforCFB has an FTN and</li><li>There is an ongoing call and NDUB condition occurs or no 180 Ringing is received prior to receiving 486 or 603 and</li><li>Number of diversions for the terminating call identified by the received History-Info header does not equal to, or exceed ‘Max Allowed Diversions for CFD Busy’ and ‘Max Allowed Diversions’.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>If the external call control node returns 486 busy, CTAS-B sends CCBS possible indication to CTAS-A. CTAS-A informs user A that CCBS is possible and gets confirmation to invoke CCBS. CTAS-A subscribes for CCBS notification from CTAS-B.</p><p>UE-A</p><p>INVITE (from:A, to: B, SDP1)</p><ul><li><ol><li>SCF</li></ol></li></ul><p>(AB)</p><p>TAS</p><p>(A)</p><p>TAS</p><p>(B)</p><p>Ext. Suspensio</p><p>CCBS Recall</p><p>MRFP</p><p>UE-B</p><p>MRFC/</p><p>CTAS</p><p>(B)</p><p>CTAS</p><p>(A)</p><p>S-CSCF</p><p>(AB)</p><p>UE-A</p><h3><a id="7.4.10 Ring Back Tone (RBT)"></a><a id="_bookmark146"></a><a id="_bookmark146"></a>Ring Back Tone (RBT)</h3><p>The personalized Ring Back Tone (RBT) service allows the user to replace the standard ring back tone with a personalized tone of the user’s choice.</p><p>The RBT service which the CTAS supports is described as follows:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>RBT is a subscription based service hence will be invoked only if the corresponding flag is enabled in the user profile.</li><li>RBT is not applied in case of early forwarding.</li><li>When late forwarding gets invoked, then depending on configuration:<ul><li>RBT of diverting party is stopped; or</li><li>RBT of diverting party is continued until the call is answered by the diverted-to party or the call fails or the diverted-to network plays some early media (e.g. announcement).</li></ul></li><li>RBT is not applied for the diverted call at the CTAS serving the diverted-to party.</li><li>For the served user with RBT and MSIM service active, one RBT is played irrespective of number of ringing MSIM devices.</li><li>RBT player is external to CTAS and the CTAS will establish additional call leg towards the RBT player.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the RBT Use Case Description document <a href="#_bookmark23">[34] </a>for details.</p><h3><a id="7.4.11 CNAP"></a><a id="_bookmark147"></a><a id="_bookmark147"></a>CNAP</h3><p>This feature allows the name of the calling party to be delivered to the called party if the called party has subscribed to the CNAP feature. CNAP is a terminating user feature allowing the CTAS connected to a switching system to receive a calling party's name during the first silent interval.</p><p>When a terminating call request is received and display-name is not received in the P-Asserted-Identity of the From header and if the served user has CNAP subscription active, TCAP Name Query is generated to retrieve the calling name of the originating user.</p><p>If display-name is received in the P-Asserted-Identity or the From header, based on configuration it is possible to generate TCAP Name query and override the display-name received.</p><p>When TCAP Name query is successful and if the presentation is not restricted, the name returned in the response is used to set the display-name of the P-Asserted-Identity and the From header.</p><h3><a id="7.4.12 Explicit Communication Transfer ("></a><a id="_bookmark148"></a><a id="_bookmark148"></a>Explicit Communication Transfer (ECT)</h3><p>The explicit communication transfer (ECT) service provides a party involved in a communication to transfer that communication to a third party.</p><p>The CTAS supports the 3PCC procedures for ECT service as defined in 3GPP TS 24.629 <a href="#_bookmark44">[58]. </a>The following types of call transfer are supported:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><em>Blind Transfer </em>- The transferor has no ongoing consultation communication with the transfer target. The transferor wants to perform the transfer without any further action on the transfer operation.</li><li><em>Assured Transfer </em>– The transferor has no ongoing consultation communication with the transfer target. The transferor wants to have a feedback on the transfer operation progress with the possibility to retrieve the communication with the transferee.</li><li><em>Consultative Transfer </em>- The transferor has a consultation communication with the transfer target. Some of the main characteristics of the ECT service supported by the CTAS are:</li><li>The CTAS supports subscription based ECT service.</li><li>The CTAS uses procedures specified in 3GPP TS 24.628 <a href="#_bookmark11">[21] </a>for special REFER request handling using 3PCC procedures.</li><li>The transferor CTAS remains in the signaling path even after the communication is transferred as specified in 3GPP TS 24.629 <a href="#_bookmark44">[58].</a></li><li>The CTAS applies classical charging model i.e. charging continues for the transferred call, fresh charging is applied for the transfer leg on both originating (transferor) and terminating (transfer target) legs as applicable as specified in Appendix C of 3GPP TS 24.629 <a href="#_bookmark44">[58].</a></li><li>The CTAS does not un-hold the transferred call. It is expected that the transfer target will un-hold the call using appropriate SDP directionality.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h2><a id="7.5 Other Services"></a><a id="_bookmark149"></a><a id="_bookmark149"></a>Other Services</h2><h3><a id="7.5.1 Multi-SIM"></a><a id="_bookmark150"></a><a id="_bookmark150"></a>Multi-SIM</h3><p>Multi-SIM (or MSIM) is a service to support several mobile devices belonging to a single user under one visible public MSISDN, which is called the Master-MSISDN. The user can have up to 5 SIM cards with one primary (or Master) and one to four reserve (or Slave) SIMs. The MSIM service makes use of normal SIM cards with their own IMSIs and MSISDNs.</p><p>Some of the main characteristics of MSIM service supported at CTAS are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>For mobile originating calls, each device is used independently. The calling line id visible to the B party is always that of the Master-MSISDN.</li><li>MSIM subscriber is disallowed from having more than one call (active or held) at the same time in more than one device, when in IMS domain.</li><li>For mobile terminating calls, the call handling will be as described below:<ul><li>If all devices are idle, parallel outgoing session requests are made to each device, with the first accepting device being connected and the others legs being disconnected.</li><li>If any of the MSIM member devices is busy, the busy device is chosen for termination, which may result in CW or CFB, based on the service settings of the Master-MSISDN.</li></ul></li><li>The originating and terminating supplementary services are normally (independent from MSIM) handled on IMPU level, Operator Determined Barrings are configured and executed per IMSI/IMPI (to allow barring of single devices/SIM cards in the case of loss)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the MSIM Use Case description document <a href="#_bookmark20">[31] </a>for details.</p><h3><a id="7.5.2 Multi UA Forking"></a><a id="_bookmark151"></a><a id="_bookmark151"></a>Multi UA Forking</h3><p>Multi Instance is a service similar to MSIM service except that it is a single SIM service, with the user registering one or more UA instances using the same IMPU.This feature allows IMS subscribers to receive call requests on different UA instances registered as a contact against the same public user identity, increasing the reachability. In order to allow this feature to be triggered, a subscriber must be previously registered with more than one UA instance defined using the same public user identity.</p><p>The scope of this document is limited to parallel forking when more than one UA instances registered from a primary and/or secondary device. The scope also includes use case where all the UA instances are registered from primary device. Under such condition, the CTAS attempts sequential forking to all the registered UA instances from primary device.</p><p>Some of the main characteristics of Single SIM Multi UA Forking service supported at CTAS are:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>For mobile originating calls, each registered UA instance can be used independently, the CTAS tracks the served user instance state using the Instance-ID.</li><li>The served user is allowed to have only one ongoing session (active or held) at any point of time when in IMS domain.</li><li>For mobile terminating calls, the following gives the overview of the call handling for parallel forking:<ul><li>The CTAS identifies the User state and generates the target list with the list of IMS/CS idle UA instances.</li><li>If there is any busy instance, the request is terminated to the busy instance depending on the subscription to Call Waiting Service.</li><li>If there are multiple UA Instance registered on the Primary Device, the call requests is forked sequentially to the one or more UA instances. The order among UUID-based and IMEI-based UA instances is configurable, with UUID-based instance defaulted as the preferred. The CS attached instance if available, will be attempted after attempting any PS/IMS registered UA instances.</li><li>In conjunction with the sequential forking to the Multiple UA instances registered on the Primary Device, the call request is parallel forked to Multiple UA Instances registered on Secondary devices.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h3><a id="7.5.3 Unstructured Supplementary Service"></a><a id="_bookmark152"></a><a id="_bookmark152"></a>Unstructured Supplementary Services Data (USSD)</h3><p>CTAS has an integrated USSI Application Server function which provides support for mobile initiated USSD operations to IMS registered UEs. The integrated USSI AS at the CTAS supports following variants of the USSD solution:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>3GPP TS 24.290 based USSD</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>This is a standard based solution for which provides the support for UE initiated MMI-mode USSD operations, which enables the transparent transport of MMI strings entered by the user to the IM core network and enables the transparent transport of text strings from the IM core network which are displayed by the UE for user information. Using this solution, the USSD messages can be transported in SIP INFO requests and SIP BYE requests, using a application/vnd.3gpp.ussd+xml MIME body.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>SMS Class 0 based USSD</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>This is a non-standard solution where the CTAS provides support for USSD within IMS via the IP Short Message procedures defined in 3GPP TS 24.341. Specifically, the CTAS will convey a USSD response to the IMS registered UE via an encapsulated SMS Class 0 RPDU using the application/vnd.3gpp.sms MIME type. Class 0 SMs are immediately display and acknowledged, but not stored on the UE.</p><p>This solution is a workaround for devices which are not compliant to the 3GPP TS 24.290 based USSD solution. There is no need for any special adaptation needed at the client to support this solution.</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Proprietary application/ussd content based USSD</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>This is a proprietary solution, which transports USSD messages using proprietary MIME type within the SIP MESSAGE. This requires adaptation at the device to be able to display the USSD message content.</p><p>When an Initial INVITE Request is received with the Request-URI containing USSD dial string, if the Recv-Info header field containing the g.3gpp.ussd info-package name is included, the 3GPP 24.290 based USSD solution to chosen by the CTAS.</p><p>If the Recv-Info header field is not received or not received with g.3gpp.ussd info-package, the CTAS choses between the two non-standard USSD solutions based on the configuration defined.</p><p>Refer to the USSI Use Case description document <a href="#_bookmark18">[29] </a>for details.</p><h3><a id="7.5.4 Intra IMPU Call Transfer"></a><a id="_bookmark153"></a><a id="_bookmark153"></a>Intra IMPU Call Transfer</h3><p>This feature allows a UA Instance attached (or registered) to the IMS or CS network to be able to pull or grab an established session (active or held) from another UA Instance belonging to the same Single SIM Multi UA subscriber.</p><p>Refer to the Pull based Call Transfer use cases <a href="#_bookmark43">[56] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="7.5.5 Session Discovery"></a><a id="_bookmark154"></a><a id="_bookmark154"></a>Session Discovery</h3><p>This feature allows a UA Instance attached (or registered) to the IMS network to discover sessions of other UA instances registered for the same user. This feature is a pre-requisite for Pull based Call Transfer using Replaces header containing the dialog identifier.</p><p>Refer to Session Discovery use cases <a href="#_bookmark45">[57] </a>for more details.</p><h2><a id="7.6 Service Centralization and Continuit"></a><a id="_bookmark155"></a><a id="_bookmark155"></a>Service Centralization and Continuity (SCC)</h2><p>The Service Centralization and Continuity Application Server (SCC AS) is a logical IMS application server that primarily provides call signaling anchoring capability. SCC AS acts as a SIP back-to-back user agent (B2BUA).</p><p>3GPP has defined the single radio call continuity procedures enabling UE moving from one access technology to another while in a call. The UE is assumed to be able to use one RAT at a time and hence it is named Single Radio Voice Call Continuity (SRVCC).</p><p>All voice sessions originated by the UE within IMS are anchored in the IMS domain at SCC AS. SCC AS is an evolution of VCC AS, which was originally defined as part of IMS Centralized Services (ICS) solution (3GPP TS 23.292). Using methods defined by 3GPP in ICS solution, the user sessions (whether using CS access or PS access) are anchored in IMS/SCC AS and thus service consistency is ensured.</p><p>The 3GPP R10 defined reference architecture for SRVCC is shown below.</p><p><strong>Mw / Mx</strong></p><p><strong>Gm</strong></p><p><strong>CS Access</strong></p><p><strong>P-CSCF</strong></p><p><strong>UE</strong></p><p><strong>Mw/I 2**</strong></p><p><strong>ISC</strong></p><p><strong>Mw/Mx</strong></p><p><strong>ATCF *</strong></p><p><strong>I /S-CSCF</strong></p><p><strong>SCC AS</strong></p><p><strong>ATGW *</strong></p><p><strong>Iq/Ix</strong></p><p><strong>MSC Server</strong></p><p>*: Location of functionality depends on deployment and collocation scenario</p><p>**: Reference point dependent on MSC Server capa.bility</p><p>The Mavenir SCC AS provides the following functions:</p><ol><li><strong>IMS Centralized Services: </strong>The SCC AS acts as an SCP for Mobile Originations in CS domain and re-directs origination/termination to IMS to enable centralization of MMTEL services.</li><li><strong>Terminating Access Domain Selection (T-ADS): </strong>The SCC AS is responsible for selecting the domain (PS or CS) for a terminating session setup request that is anchored and then actual session termination in the selected domain.</li><li><strong>CS Retry: </strong>The SCC AS is responsible for performing CS Retry for a terminating session setup request that is anchored when the PS session termination request fails.</li><li><strong>Access Transfer: </strong>The SCC AS is responsible for keeping a special number required for Access Transfer up-to-date in HSS and also for handling Access Transfer requests received and updating the remote leg when required.</li></ol><p>Refer to the SCC AS Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark40">[53] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="7.6.1 IMS Centralized Services (ICS)"></a><a id="_bookmark156"></a><a id="_bookmark156"></a>IMS Centralized Services (ICS)</h3><p>ICS aims at providing consistent services no matter what access network is used (CS or PS). With ICS, all services are provided by the IMS application servers and controlled by the IMS service control architecture. Hence CS users can benefit from the new IMS services while still using CS domain for the media bearer. ICS treats IMS sessions with CS bearer like any other full IMS session. With ICS all user sessions are controlled by the IMS core network. The ICS architecture is based on the usage of an enhanced MSC server acting as a SIP User Agent on behalf of the CS UE and making signaling adaptation between the CS and the IMS. The SCC AS is responsible for anchoring the user sessions and executing the transfer between PS and CS domains.</p><p>3GPP has specified in 3GPP TS 23.237 <a href="#_bookmark35">[47] </a>and 3GPP TS 23.292 <a href="#_bookmark36">[48] </a>the principles for centralization and continuity of services in the IMS in order to provide consistent services to the user regardless of the attached access type. In order to support this principle, all originated and terminated sessions via the CS or PS domains need to be anchored in the Service Centralization and Continuity Application Server (SCC AS) in the IMS. The SCC AS must be inserted in the session path using the originating and terminating initial Filter</p><p>Criteria (iFC). The SCC AS is configured as the first AS in the originating iFC and as the last AS in the terminating iFC chain.</p><h4><a id="7.6.1.1 Session Anchoring"></a><a id="_bookmark157"></a><a id="_bookmark157"></a>Session Anchoring</h4><p>As specified in 3GPP TS 23.237 <a href="#_bookmark35">[47] </a>and 3GPP TS 23.292 <a href="#_bookmark36">[48], </a>all sessions originated and terminated when using the PS or CS access are anchored in the IMS network at the SCC AS.</p><p>The SCC AS anchors all sessions originated in PS domain along with the associated terminating sessions in PS or CS domain. When the session is originated in the CS domain, the anchoring of this origination session in the IMS network requires the MSC to route the originated session to the IMS network. Similarly when the session originated in CS domain has to be terminated to the user with IMS subscription, the MSC is required to route the terminated session to the IMS network. When the MSC server is enhanced for ICS, the call routing is achieved using the procedures defined in 3GPP TS 23.292 <a href="#_bookmark36">[48] </a>over the I2 interface.</p><img id="_bookmark158"></a><a id="_bookmark158"></a>Supplementary Services</h4><p>Supplementary Services configured in the UDR may be configured with a split view or a shared view. In the split view, the Services data configuration is split between the domains i.e. the HLR-view will contain services which must be invoked when only in CS domain, while the MMTEL-view will contain services to be invoked in IMS domain. For example, the CDIV services which are terminating services are expected to be invoked when the user is in IMS domain, hence these services will not be configured in the HLR- view of the user profile.</p><p>In the shared view, the same set of services is available irrespective of the domain of the user.</p><h4><a id="7.6.1.2.1 Split View"></a><a id="7.6.1.2.1 Split View"></a>Split View</h4><p>Supplementary services in the CS and IMS domain are applied as follows:</p><p>Originations</p><p>Made over CS access</p><p>Originating services provided by MSC</p><p>Made over PS/IMS access</p><p>Originating services provided by CTAS</p><p>Terminations</p><p>All mobile terminating call attempts made to a user with an IMS voice subscription are routed to IMS/CTAS.</p><p>T-ADS procedure invoked by CTAS determines IMS voice over PS is supported</p><p>Services provided by CTAS</p><p>Call termination attempt first made via IMS, with a retry via CS being performed for a configurable set of error scenarios</p><p>T-ADS procedure invoked by CTAS determines IMS voice over PS support is unknown</p><p>Services provided by CTAS</p><p>CS breakout is performed</p><p>The table below summarizes the location for supplementary service invocation. The column “B on IMS” implies that the subscriber is on a RAT for which IMS voice is supported.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Service</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>A on CS</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>A on IMS</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Note (A side)</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>B on CS</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>B on IMS</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Note (B side)</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>OIP</p></td><td><p>n/a</p></td><td><p>n/a</p></td><td></td><td><p>CTAS &amp; Current release does not support anchoring of originating sessions when the user is attached to CS domain.</p><p>Terminations</p><p>All mobile terminating call attempts made to a user with an IMS voice subscription are routed to IMS/CTAS, when Static Routing of CS Originated calls are used. When dynamic routing option is used, mobile terminating call attempts made to a IMS registered is routed to IMS/CTAS.</p><p>T-ADS procedure invoked by CTAS determines IMS voice over PS is supported</p><p>Services provided by CTAS</p><p>Call termination attempt first made via IMS, with a retry via CS being performed for a configurable set of error scenarios. When Dynamic routing option is used, it could still be possible that the user is registered in IMS, but not reachable in IMS.</p><p>T-ADS procedure invoked by CTAS determines IMS voice over PS support is unknown</p><p>Services provided by CTAS</p><p>CS breakout is performed</p><p>The table below summarizes the location for supplementary service invocation. id="7.7 IM-SSF"></a><a id="_bookmark159"></a><a id="_bookmark159"></a>IM-SSF</h2><p>CTAS also supports an integrated IM-SSF (i.e. gsmSSF) function. Refer to the IN IW Use cases <a href="#_bookmark26">[37] </a>for more details.</p><h2><a id="7.8 iSCP"></a><a id="_bookmark160"></a><a id="_bookmark160"></a>iSCP</h2><p>CTAS supports an integrated gsmSCF function which is designed to provide similar service as that of the IN SCP. The current scope of this function is limited to facilitating the ICS functionality as described in Section <strong>Error! Reference source not found.</strong>.</p><p>Below described are the two services supported at the iSCP:</p><h4>ICS Mg MO redirection (static or dynamic)</h4><p>This service enables redirection of CS originated MOC calls into the IMS domain using the Mg interface i.e. between MGCF and the I-CSCF. This enables IMS Centralized Services (ICS) based service control for this session.</p><h4>ICS Mg MT redirection (static or dynamic)</h4><p>This service enables redirection of MTC CS calls into the IMS domain using the Mg interface i.e. between MGCF and the I-CSCF. This enables IMS Centralized Services (ICS) based service control for this session.</p><p>iSCP supports following interface protocol for providing the above services:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>CAP v2, v3</li><li>INAP CS-1, CS-2</li><li>ANSI-41 ver E</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>iSCP supports the below messages over the CAP/INAP interface:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>InitialDP (IDP)</li><li>Connect (CON)</li><li>Continue (CUE)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>iSCP supports the below messages over ANSI-41 interface:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>AnalyzedInformation (ANLYZD)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to Section 3.5 of SCC AS Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark40">[53] </a>for more details.</p><h2><a id="7.9 User Configuration of SS (Supplement"></a><a id="_bookmark161"></a><a id="_bookmark161"></a>User Configuration of SS (Supplementary Services)</h2><p>CTAS supports the following two methods of User Configuration of SS:</p><ul><li>Ut interface using XCAP as described in 3GPP TS 24.623</li><li>SIP based User Config as described in 3GPP TS 24.238</li></ul><h3><a id="7.9.1 Ut Interface using XCAP"></a><a id="_bookmark162"></a><a id="_bookmark162"></a>Ut Interface using XCAP</h3><p>The XML Configuration Access Protocol (XCAP), defined in RFC 4825, is used on the Ut interface to allow an XCAP client to read, write and modify application configuration data which is stored in XML format on an XCAP server. This is referred to as the simservs XML document.</p><p>For VoLTE, the XCAP client resides in the UE and the XCAP server resides in the CTAS. 3GPP TS 24.623 defines a supplementary services XCAP application usage which allows the UE to read, write and modify supplementary services data that is stored in the network.</p><p>CTAS supports the Ut interface as defined in 3GPP TS 24.623 <a href="#_bookmark17">[27] </a>which includes:</p><ul><li>Interrogation of following supplementary services:<ul><li>Originating Identification Presentation (OIP)</li><li>Originating Identification Restriction (OIR)</li><li>Terminating Identification Presentation (TIP)</li><li>Terminating Identification Restriction (TIR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding Unconditional (CFU)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Busy (CFB)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on No Reachable (CFNRc)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on No Reply (CFNR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Not-Logged In (CFNL)</li><li>Communication Waiting (CW)</li><li>Incoming Communication Barring (ICB)</li><li>Outgoing Communication Barring (OCB)</li></ul></li><li>Manipulation of following supplementary services:<ul><li>Originating Identification Presentation (OIP)</li><li>Originating Identification Restriction (OIR)</li><li>Terminating Identification Presentation (TIP)</li><li>Terminating Identification Restriction (TIR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding Unconditional (CFU)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Busy (CFB)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on No Reachable (CFNRc)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on No Reply (CFNR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Not-Logged In (CFNL)</li><li>Communication Waiting (CW)</li><li>Incoming Communication Barring (ICB)</li><li>Outgoing Communication Barring (OCB)</li></ul></li></ul><p>Note that CTAS supports configurable control over the Ut operations allowed by the XCAP server function in CTAS. So for example, CTAS can be configured to support the interrogation of services such as OIP, OIR, TIP, TIR, etc.</p><p>CTAS supports operations on the entire XML document and also supports node selector functionality which allows operations to be performed on specific XML elements and attributes.</p><p>CTAS does not provide any authentication of XCAP requests received over the Ut interface, but instead requires an external and intermediate node to perform this function.</p><p>Refer to the Ut Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark21">[32] </a>for further details.</p><p>CTAS supports updating the User config changes to the UDR over the following interfaces:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>LDAP Interface</li><li>SPML Interface</li><li>Sh Interface</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><h3><a id="7.9.2 SIP based User Config"></a><a id="_bookmark163"></a><a id="_bookmark163"></a>SIP based User Config</h3><p>SIP-based protocol framework serves as a means of user configuration of supplementary services in the backend user profle database. The contents of the Request-URI in a SIP INVITE request is used to convey the configuration code to the CTAS that hosts the supplementary service. Upon session initiation, the contents of the Request-URI are delivered by means of normal session setup signalling. The CTAS then acts upon the Request-URI contents to effect the desired configuration data change (e.g., register and activate Communication Forwarding unconditional).</p><p>CTAS supports manipulation of following supplementary services:</p><ul><li>Originating Identification Presentation (OIP)</li><li>Originating Identification Restriction (OIR)</li><li>Terminating Identification Presentation (TIP)</li><li>Terminating Identification Restriction (TIR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding Unconditional (CFU)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Busy (CFB)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on No Reachable (CFNRc)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on No Reply (CFNR)</li><li>Communication Forwarding on Not-Logged In (CFNL)</li><li>Communication Waiting (CW)</li><li>Incoming Communication Barring (ICB)</li><li>Outgoing Communication Barring (OCB)</li><li>All Call Forwarding (ALLCF)</li></ul><h2><a id="7.10 Error Handling"></a><a id="_bookmark164"></a><a id="_bookmark164"></a>Error Handling</h2><p>The Error Handling framework defines a common control to handle all the errors generated at the CTAS due to an external or an internal trigger. As part of this framework, the final action when a particular error is received is determined by the action configured against the internal cause code generated. Any external error received is first mapped to an internal cause code before determining any further action.</p><p>In addition to the Internal cause code, the following are the other input criteria (s) used to determine the final action for a particular Internal cause code generated:</p><ul><li>Session Type – Identifies the type of session.</li><li>Organization – Identifies the Organization associated with the served user.</li><li>Application Type – Identifies the MMTEL sub-application set by the APPCFG translation profile prior to call request processing.</li><li>Account Type – Identifies the account-type for a subscriber indicating a categorization of prepay or post-pay status.</li><li>Call Event – Identifies the Call Event type associated with this call.</li><li>Roam Type – Identifies the Roaming Status of the served user.</li></ul><p>The action (or the behavior) set for the configured internal cause codes are:</p><ul><li>Play Announcement and Tone (PLAY_ANNCTONE) – This action instructs the CTAS to reject the call after playing the configured Announcement and Tone. For example, when the outgoing calls are barred, this action when set against the outgoing calls barred specific Internal Cause Code will result in the caller hearing an announcement followed by a tone, before the call is terminated.</li><li>Play Announcement (PLAY_ANNC) – This action instructs the CTAS to reject the call after playing the configured Announcement. The Tones table is skipped, but it could be possible that the Tone could be part of the announcement file configured in the Announcement table itself.</li><li>Play Tone (PLAY_TONE) – This action instructs the CTAS to reject the call after playing the configured Tone.</li><li>Play Prompt and Collect (PLAY_PAC) – This action instructs the CTAS to Prompt for more information from the Caller. This action is mainly used for service specific cause code like that set for CCBS Activation prompt.</li><li>Play Announcement and continue (PLAY_ANNC_CON) – This action instructs the CTAS to continue with the call routing with a (possibly modified) destination address after playing an announcement.</li><li>Play Announcement and redirect (PLAY_ANNC_RDR) – This action instructs the CTAS to redirect the call after playing an announcement. The destination address to be used for redirection is configured against this particular cause code.</li><li>Continue (CONTINUE) – This action instructs the CTAS to continue with the call routing with a (possibly modified) destination address without playing an announcement.</li><li>Redirect (REDIRECT) - This action instructs the CTAS to redirect the call without playing an announcement. The destination address to be used for redirection is configured against this particular cause code.</li></ul><p>The default action when there is no matching entry found in this table would be to reject the call without playing any announcement.</p><p>The Error Handling will be invoked at the CTAS under the following conditions:</p><ul><li>Any external SIP or Q.850 error response received;</li><li>Any internal failure generated due to failure in services provided by the CTAS, like Ro charging, supplementary service like barring, etc.</li><li>Any other internal failure causing a release of the call.</li></ul><h2><a id="7.11 Announcements and Tones"></a><a id="_bookmark165"></a><a id="_bookmark165"></a>Announcements and Tones</h2><p>Announcements may be sent during the establishment of a communication session, when rejecting a communication request, during an established communication session or during the release of a communication session.</p><p>The announcement may be network provided or IN induced. A network provided announcement is triggered due to receiving of backward causes or any other internal error requiring clearing of the call. The CW tone/announcement, Hold tone/announcement and local ringtone is also considered network provided announcement.</p><p>CTAS supports playing announcements and/or tones during following scenarios:</p><ul><li>Session Reject - A service may provide an announcement when rejecting a communication request e.g. in order to explain the reason for rejecting the communication request in more detail. If an announcement is provided the service will use early media for sending the announcement in-band in an early dialog and using the P-Early-Media header field authorizing early media and insert the Reason header with the proper cause value.</li><li>Session Establishment - A service may provide an announcement during the establishment of a communication. If an announcement is provided the service will:<ul><li>Use early media for sending the announcement in-band in an early dialog and using the P-Early-Media header field authorizing early media or</li><li>Use multiple early dialogs and using P-Early-Media header field authorizing early media.</li></ul></li></ul><p>Examples of announcement played during session establishment are local ring tone, call waiting tone or any other IN induced announcement/tone.</p><ul><li>Established communication - A service may provide an announcement during an established communication. If an announcement is provided the service will:<ul><li>Use the existing media stream. The media stream may have to be re-negotiated by the service to a media type suitable for the announcement.</li></ul></li></ul><p>Examples of announcement played in established communication are IN induced prepaid warning tone, announcement to held user &amp; Ro charging session update failure.</p><p>Refer to the Announcement/Tone Use Case document <a href="#_bookmark22">[33] </a>for details.</p><h2><a id="7.12 Lawful Interception"></a><a id="_bookmark166"></a><a id="_bookmark166"></a>Lawful Interception</h2><p>The Lawful Interception (LI) is an action based on the law, performed by operator of making available certain information and providing that information to a law enforcement agency’s monitoring facility.</p><p>From the CTAS perspective, the LI functionality comprises of following tasks:</p><ul><li>Administration of LI-requests</li><li>Transfer of the interception output to the Law Enforcement Agencies ('LEA').</li></ul><p>In order to provide LI functionality, the CTAS interwork with Utimaco’s Lawful Interception Management (LIMS) System. The CTAS supports following interface defined by Utimaco’s LIMS systems</p><ul><li>The administration interface (X1) of the LIMS is used to provision the interception measures (called LI targets) on the CTAS.<ul><li>Note:<ul><li>Target interception can be the phone number MSISDN in (TEL_URI) or the URI of a SIP server (SIP_URI), IMEI/IMEISV or IMSI</li><li>CTAS supports up to 20,000 unique interception targets</li><li>CTAS supports interception of same targets by multiple LEA’s</li></ul></li></ul></li><li>The Control Plane Interface (X2) is used by the CTAS to transport intercepted signaling information (both call and non-call related) to/from network element using the protocol defined by the Utimaco’s LIMS system.</li><li>The CTAS supports SSL/TLS as encryption algorithm over X1/X2 interface. The CTAS supports interception of following events</li><li>Interception of Subscriber Controlled Input (SCI)</li></ul><p>The CTAS receives User Configuration of Supplementary Services (SCI) from the UE over Ut interface.</p><ul><li>Intercept conferencing events</li></ul><p>The CTAS intercepts following conferencing events when the target of the interception is involved in the conference (either as a controller and/or as a party to the conference (including remote users)</p><ul><li><ul><li>Creation of Conference</li><li>Party Join</li><li>Party Leave</li><li>\tConference Bearer Modification. For example:<ul><li>When a party to a conference successfully modifies (i.e., add, remove, change) a bearer stream in the conference.</li><li>When a party to a conference unsuccessfully attempts to modify (i.e., add, remove, change) a bearer stream in the conference.</li></ul></li><li>Start of Intercept on an Active Conference</li><li>End of Conference; (Conference Host)</li></ul></li></ul><p>The interception output is called Interception Related Information (IRI) a.k.a LITicket and it contains signaling events.</p><p>The LITicket to be transmitted to the LEAs via delivery functions (DF) of the LIMS are defined for each target during provisioning. The CTAS transmits the LITicket(s) over X2 interface to the configured DF2 address,</p><p>The CTAS re-transmits the LITicket(s) to the configured retransmission interval for up to the configured number of reattempts (This could be due to X2 link between LIMS and CTAS going down).</p><p>In case re-transmission resulted in failure, the CTAS stores the intercepted LITicket(s) in secure buffer for configured duration in persistent memory, upon expiry of the timer the buffer is permanently deleted.</p><p>Upon detection of X2 link failure, the CTAS raises alarm and the alarm is cleared only when the X2 link is up.</p><h2><a id="7.13 Charging"></a><a id="_bookmark167"></a><a id="_bookmark167"></a>Charging</h2><p>CTAS provides function that implement offline and/or online charging mechanisms. In offline charging, the resource usage is reported from the network to the Billing Domain after the resource usage has occurred. In online charging, a subscriber account, located in an online charging system, is queried prior to granting permission to use the requested network resource(s).</p><p>Offline and online charging may be performed simultaneously and independently for the same chargeable event.</p><h3><a id="7.13.1 Online Charging"></a><a id="_bookmark168"></a><a id="_bookmark168"></a>Online Charging</h3><p>Online charging is a process where charging information for network resource usage is collected concurrently with that resource usage in the same fashion as in offline charging. However, authorization for the network resource usage is obtained by the network prior to the actual resource usage to occur. This authorization is granted by the Online Charging System upon request from the network.</p><p>When receiving a network resource usage request, the network assembles the relevant charging information and generates a charging event towards the OCS in real-time. The OCS then returns an appropriate resource usage authorization. The resource usage authorization received in the units of time ( duration in seconds), therefore the authorization may have to be renewed from time to time as long as the user’s network resource usage persists.</p><p>In conclusion, online charging is a mechanism where charging information can affect, in real-time, the service rendered and therefore a direct interaction of the charging mechanism with the control of network resource usage is required.</p><p>CTAS supports the below defined mechanisms for Online charging, which may be performed independent of each other.</p><h4><a id="7.13.1.1 IN"></a><a id="_bookmark169"></a><a id="_bookmark169"></a>IN</h4><p>The IN based charging is triggered based on the O-CSI or T-CSI subscription received as part of the service data retrieved from the UDR/HSS.</p><p>Refer to the IN Interworking use case document <a href="#_bookmark26">[37] </a>for more details.</p><h4><a id="7.13.1.2 Ro"></a><a id="_bookmark170"></a><a id="_bookmark170"></a>Ro</h4><p>The CTAS supports Session Charging with Unit Reservation (SCUR) as defined in 3GPP TS 32.260; this includes procedures for requesting service units and returning used units during sessions. The “unit” measurement supported by CTAS is time (in units of seconds), CTAS performs quota management of the received units upon session answer i.e. By default upon receiving ACK for 200 OK for initial INVITE.</p><p>The CTAS supports online charging using Ro for the following session type</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Mobile originated voice and video call</li><li>Mobile originated videoshare call</li><li>Mobile Terminated voice and video call or selectively Mobile Terminated calls when roaming,</li><li>Upgrade and downgrade of voice and video call respectively.</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Further, CTAS supports online charging via Ro for the following supplementary services for voice call:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Communication Diversion (CDIV), i.e. call forwarding</li><li>Conferencing (CONF)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Refer to the Ro interface specification document <a href="#_bookmark31">[43] </a>for more details.</p><h3><a id="7.13.2 Offline Charging"></a><a id="_bookmark171"></a><a id="_bookmark171"></a>Offline Charging</h3><p>Offline charging is a process where charging information for network resource usage is collected concurrently with that resource usage. The charging information is then passed through a chain of logical charging functions that are further explained in clause 4.3.1. At the end of this process, CDR files are generated by the network, which are then transferred to the network operator's Billing Domain for the purpose of subscriber billing and/or inter-operator accounting (or additional functions, e.g. statistics, at the operator’s discretion). The BD typically comprises post-processing systems such as the operator's billing system or billing mediation device.</p><p>In conclusion, offline charging is a mechanism where charging information does not affect, in real-time, the service rendered.</p><p>CTAS supports the below defined mechanisms for Offline charging, which are mutually exclusive.</p><h4><a id="7.13.2.1 Rf"></a><a id="_bookmark172"></a><a id="_bookmark172"></a>Rf</h4><p>Offline charging using Rf interface consists of the CTAS reporting accounting information to the CDF upon receiving various SIP requests and/or SIP responses. This reporting is achieved by sending Diameter Accounting-Request (ACR) command to the CDF. There are four ACR types: Start, Interim, Stop and Event.</p><p>The CTAS supports Session Charging and Event based offline charging using Rf interface as defined in 3GPP TS 32.260 and as explained below:</p><p>The CTAS supports two basic charging scenarios:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><strong>Session-based charging </strong>– This type of charging is used for reporting successfully answered voice and video sessions:</li><li><strong>Event-based charging </strong>– This type of charging is used for reporting non-session related events, such as IMS registrations, failed call setup attempts or SCI operations</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>The CTAS supports offline charging using Rf interface for the following session type</p><p>Third Party Registration</p><p>Mobile originated voice call</p><p>Mobile terminated voice call</p><p>Further, CTAS supports offline charging using Rf interface for all supplementary services as listed in this document section <a href="#_bookmark130">7.4.</a></p><p>Refer to the Rf interface specification document <a href="#_bookmark27">[38] </a>for more details.</p><h4><a id="7.13.2.2 CDR"></a><a id="_bookmark173"></a><a id="_bookmark173"></a>CDR</h4><p>The CTAS supports generation of following types of CDR</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>MMTel CDR</li><li>SCI CDR</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Of this, the CTAS supports generation of MMTel CDR for complete session or partial MMTel CDR i.e. a MMTel CDR that provides information on part of a user session.</p><p>Partial CDRs if generated by the CTAS are always “Fully Qualified Partial CDR” i.e. it contains a complete set of the fields specified for the CDR. This includes all the mandatory and conditional fields for that session with values available at the time of partial CDR record generation.</p><p>The CTAS supports CDR generation for the following session type</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Third Party Registration</li><li>Mobile originated voice and video call</li><li>Mobile terminated voice and video call</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>Further, CTAS supports CDR generation for all supplementary services as listed in this document section <a href="#_bookmark130">7.4</a></p><p>Refer to the CDR interface specification document <a href="#_bookmark39">[52] </a>for more details.</p><h2><a id="7.14 Operational"></a><a id="_bookmark174"></a><a id="_bookmark174"></a>Operational</h2><h3><a id="7.14.1 Backup and Restore"></a><a id="_bookmark175"></a><a id="_bookmark175"></a>Backup and Restore</h3><p>The Backup and Restore software module runs on the AM blade and manages the automatic (i.e. scheduled) backup process and the coordination of the backup procedures between the active and standby blades. The Backup and Restore module also supports on-demand backup requests.</p><p>The following data is backed up:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Blade</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Backup Files</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>AM blades</p></td><td><ol><li>mOne system software, i.e. software images for each blade</li><li>Linux configuration files</li><li>3rd party software</li></ol></td></tr><tr><td><p>SE Blades</p></td><td><p>All necessary files required to restore the SE configuration, e.g. VLAN configuration files</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Database</p></td><td><p>All system configuration related to application, ems, etc.</p></td></tr></table><p>System configuration is provided for the following:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>Scheduled backup times</li><li>Directory path for backups</li><li>Backup timeout timers</li><li>Length of time to keep each backup file</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>3rd party agents can be installed on the AM blade to periodically copy the backup files to external storage. A Backup and Restore Method of Procedure (MOP) will be provided with the product documentation.</p><h3><a id="7.14.2 User Authorization"></a><a id="_bookmark176"></a><a id="_bookmark176"></a>User Authorization</h3><p>The CTAS system administrator enforces policy management and assigns user access privileges and roles to personnel using the EMS GUI or Centralized Management Server (CMS). There are four types of roles defined:</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>User Roles</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Description</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Super Administrator</p></td><td><p>A Super Administrator is allowed to do the following:</p><ul><li>Add, delete and modify privileges for all parameters</li><li>Add, delete and modify access permissions for all users</li><li>Perform system backup</li><li>Initiate software upgrades and downgrades</li></ul></td></tr></table><table><tr><td><p><strong>User Roles</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Description</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Administrator</p></td><td><p>An Administrator is allowed to do the following:</p><ul><li>Add, delete and modify privileges for all parameters</li><li>View permissions</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><p>User / Operator</p></td><td><p>A User / Operator is allowed do to the following:</p><ul><li>View the privileges for all parameters</li><li>Add, delete and modify a subset of all parameters</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td><p>Guest</p></td><td><p>A Guest is allowed to do the following:</p><ul><li>View the privileges for all parameters</li><li>A guest cannot add, delete or modify any parameters within the system.</li></ul></td></tr></table><p>Each user is defined with the following:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>User ID</li><li>Password</li><li>Name</li><li>Email address</li><li>User role (as shown above)</li><li>Account lock status (locked or unlocked)</li><li>User type (temporary, regular)</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul><p>For each user type an access level can be defined. Access Management enables the assignment of different access levels to different type of users for configuring different elements. Hence each user group privilege is configurable on GUI. The access privilege is provided to different system elements like Quick view, Fault Alarm, Fault Event, Fault Definition, Configuration, etc.</p><p>A Method of Procedure (MOP) for all user management procedures will be provided with the product documentation.</p><h3><a id="7.14.3 Alarming"></a><a id="_bookmark177"></a><a id="_bookmark177"></a>Alarming</h3><p>The CTAS system supports two integration models for Fault Management: mView can be used in the operator NOC to monitor mOne faults, or alternatively the CTAS system can report alarms to an external 3rd party OSS for integrated Fault Management. SNMP is the interface used to pass traps related information from the mOne system to the external entities. The mOne system has the capability to send SNMP traps to more than one system, thus providing customer the ability to monitor the system across various NOC centres. Event and Alarm reporting is managed via a defined SNMPv2/v3 MIB structure that contains relevant information regarding the alarm or event. Events and alarms are collected by the Event Manager from the various applications, and then sent via SNMP to an external SNMP agent or directly to mView. The Fault Management process ensures an appropriate alarm or event for failures associated with the hardware components, communication links, and processing errors.</p><p>The Alarms and Event function in the CTAS Element Management System (EMS) provides the operator with a consolidated view of the alarm sand events generated across all blades within the system. The mOne system complies with ITU-T X.733 and X.734.</p><p>The following table summarizes the system alarm types.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Alarm Type</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Description</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Communication Alarm</p></td><td><p>A communication alarm is associated with the procedures and/or processes that convey information from one point ot another.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Processing Error Alarm</p></td><td><p>A processing error alarm indicates software or processing fault.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Equipment Alarm</p></td><td><p>An equipment alarm indicates an equipment / hardware fault.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Environmental Alarm</p></td><td><p>An environmental alarm indicates a condition relating to an enclosure where the equipment resides.</p></td></tr></table><p>The following table describes the system alarm severity levels supported.</p><table><tr><td><p><strong>Severity Level</strong></p></td><td><p><strong>Description</strong></p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Cleared</p></td><td><p>Indicates a clearing of one or more previously reported alarms. This clears all alarms for a managed object that has the same alarm type, including the probable cause and the specific problems (if given).</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Critical</p></td><td><p>Indicates a service affecting condition has occurred where immediate corrective action is required. This severity levels occurs when a managed object goes out of service and its capability must be restored.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Major</p></td><td><p>Indicates a service affecting condition has occurred where urgent corrective action is required. This severity level applies when there is a degradation in the capability of the managed object and it’s capability must be restored.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Minor</p></td><td><p>Indicates a non-service affecting fault condition has occurred where corrective action should be taken in order to prevent a more serious fault. This severity level applies when the detected alarm condition is not currently degrading the capacity or performance of the managed object.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Warning</p></td><td><p>Indicates the detection of a potential service affecting fault. This severity level applies when further action should be taken to diagnose the reported condition.</p></td></tr><tr><td><p>Indeterminate</p></td><td><p>Indicates the detection of a fault, where no severity could be associated with.</p></td></tr></table><p>The EMS GUI can be used for viewing and troubleshooting the events, as well as configuring the system for forwarding the fault events to the Operators network management system using SNMPv3.</p><h3><a id="7.14.4 Logging"></a><a id="_bookmark178"></a><a id="_bookmark178"></a>Logging</h3><p>Log management system is used to log event and/or activity that occur within the system. Log Management provides capabilities for log browsing, strategy setting, and backup. Several types of logs are supported by the mOne system, including Event, System and Admin logs. Alarm and/or event information is stored in an Event Log for a definable number of days. System logs record the start and stop of the mView system, processes or tasks, and any abnormalities of high, intermediate and low levels. Admin logs record all the administrative operations performed by the operator crafts person through the mView system. By viewing and analysing the logs, the system operator and maintenance personnel can review the operating status of the system and locate network faults. Administration Log records all the CTAS GUI user operations. It supports admin log query function. It records information’s such as, User name, IP address, Login time. It also raise an alarm, if a user fails to login after 3 consecutive attempts. It locks the user for at least 24 hours. An administration log file is created for each user. A log file is closed and a new one is opened after 7 days or when the file size is over 2M, whichever occurs first.</p><p>In addition the CTAS provides a Call Trace feature which can be used to troubleshoot data packets and failures that occur during call establishment. The Call Trace can capture the following information:</p><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li><ul><li>External Signalling messages involved in call setup, the protocols supported are:<ul><li>SIP</li><li>CAP</li><li>MAP</li><li>Diameter</li><li>LDAP</li><li>SOAP</li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul>`,
